Like Senator Kemp, the minister for sport, he is showing nothing but contempt for the people of Canberra.

The Sports Commission has already demonstrated its intransigence and its unwillingness to negotiate with the ACT government in good faith and with an open mind. We now have the spectre of the Liberal Party, both federally and locally, trying to intimidate and politically blackmail the ACT government. Minister Kemp and his mates in the ACT assembly have claimed that the AIS will pack up and move elsewhere if the western route proceeds. This is a crude form of political blackmail, and nothing could be more ludicrous. This is about Liberal bullying, because the local Liberals were crushingly defeated at the Territory election and now they are looking for an issue with which to get some kind of traction. Now we have the Liberals saying, `If this road is built, then the future of the AIS is in doubt.' We expect this type of thuggery from Minister Tuckey, but I am deeply concerned that the Sports Commission has aligned itself with the Liberals so overtly over this issue.

In November 2001, the CEO of the Sports Commission, Mr Mark Peters, wrote to the ACT Chief Minister, Jon Stanhope, saying that he would not comment publicly on this matter, yet that is exactly what Mr Peters has gone ahead and done. Long before the proposed alignment had even been finalised— and, remember, that was only on 20 June this year—the Sports Commission was releasing documents purporting to show the impact of the road and the location of the road in relation to the AIS site. I believe that there are genuine concerns about the impact of the Gungahlin Drive extension on the AIS site in Bruce and that they should be addressed; nevertheless, it was incumbent on the Sports Commission and the AIS to raise these matters in the appropriate manner and in appropriate fora. Mr Peters chose not to contact me, nor did he express to me any concerns about the Gungahlin extension.

Mr Peters admitted at Senate estimates earlier this year that there was a period of eight months during which the Sports Commission made no formal expressions to the ACT Labor Party, the ACT Liberal Party or the Greens. Later, on 22 February, Mr Peters wrote an article in the Canberra Times in which he asserted that the western route would come within 75 metres of the AIS. An erroneous map was provided showing the alleged route virtually bisecting the AIS, when in truth the road alignment is conceivably some 200 metres away from the AIS and, as we now know, will be sunk between five and seven metres below the surface of the ground. The Sports Commission also did not mention that an environmental impact statement had yet to be completed. As the Canberra Times pointed out in an editorial on 21 February, the Sports Commission and the AIS indulged in hyperbole and exaggeration. `What did the AIS expect?' asked the Canberra Times. Did it seriously imagine that an ACT election could be fought, with policies positioned and cemented and commitments given, and that afterwards it could politely ask that the federal government do its bidding? The obvious conclusion is yes, that is exactly what it expected.

I recently went out to the AIS site to hear their concerns. Their concerns about the road involved potential noise and pollution, and, as I said before, those concerns need to be addressed. I believe, however, that the ACT government has seriously tried to meet all the issues raised by both the Sports Commission and the Institute of Sport. First, construction of the road will not begin until after training for the Athens Olympics is over. Second, any noise impact will be addressed through the comprehensive Unisearch noise study and the design of the road. Third, an environmental health assessment and an air quality study are currently under way to make sure this happens. Finally, the road will be constructed five to seven metres below the surface and about 200 metres away from the AIS. These measures demonstrate that the ACT government is negotiating in good faith. It also demonstrates that the AIS has the capacity and the opportunity to accept those points of compromise with the ACT government and come to an agreement so that both the AIS and the road have a mutual future. I want to take this opportunity to urge the Liberal Party and the Sports Commission to stop playing petty politics with sport and with the institute, and I urge them to work with the ACT government to build this much needed transport link.

It is not very often in this place that something like sport—which is something we are all involved in in some way or other, or about which at least we are passionate in our support of whatever team is a current success—comes up. People involved in the Sports Commission in particular tend to rise above partisan politics. I was very disappointed to see the role that Mr Peters, in particular, played in relation to this issue about the Gungahlin Drive link. Clearly, there was significant contact between him and the local Liberal ACT assembly members and there was a concerted effort to get political mileage out of this issue. I believe that sport, and the Australian Institute of Sport in particular, should be above politics. This particular incident will hopefully go down in history as something that they regret. Hopefully, we will see the new road, the western route, built—and at the same time see the continuing fantastic success of the Australian Institute of Sport here in Canberra.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 February 2002:

question.para: (1) What is the daily at-sea operating cost inclusive of spares, POL contractor and in-house maintenance and crew costs of: (a) an FFG frigate; (b) an ANZAC frigate; (c) a Collins class submarine; (d) the former fast catamaran, Jervis Bay, while in service; (e) a Fremantle class patrol boat; and (f) by class, each other ship type in service with the Royal Australian Navy of displacement not less than 500 tons.
(2) What are the hourly operating costs, inclusive of spares, POL contractor and in-house maintenance and crew costs, by each type of aircraft in service with the Royal Australian Air Force.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Past practice in answering questions of this nature has been for Defence to provide the daily, or hourly, full-cost recovery rate for ADF assets.

The full-cost recovery rate methodology is used to calculate the recovery or waiver costs of using a particular asset, usually when Defence is asked to perform a non-Defence activity. A comprehensive set of cost factors, including management overheads, capital costs and depreciation, salaries and accrued superannuation, is used to calculate the recovery rate. In other words, the rate includes all the embedded costs that Defence would be paying whether or not the assets had been deployed on operations.
The underlying assumption in recent questions and debate, that the full cost recovery rate can be extrapolated to estimate the costs of operations is, quite simply, misleading.

The true cost to the taxpayer of undertaking additional operations is the net additional cost. The net additional cost of a particular asset in an operation, in terms of extra fuel, rations and allowances, would depend on the particular operation. It also would take account of the offsets within its overall budget Defence would make in absorbing some of that cost; for example, cancelling or postponing exercises or seeking additional efficiencies to help offset the additional costs.

The net additional cost approach outlined above is consistent with the approach taken by successive Governments in providing supplementation to the Defence budget for operations - for example, the Gulf War and peacekeeping operations in Somalia and Rwanda. It is the method that this Government intends to continue to use for its own costings and to employ when answering questions about the costs of operations for purposes of more accurate debate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) (a) When did the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) enter into a formal agreement with the sports aviation sector in relation to the administration of sports aviation and; (b) when did that agreement come into effect.
(2) Can a copy of that agreement be provided.

(3) Did that agreement impose conditions on the sports aviation sector in relation to the maintenance of ultralight aircraft; if so: (a) what were those conditions; and (b) were they provided in a technical manual that required the approval of the CAA; if so (i) when was the manual approved, and (ii) can a copy be provided.

(4) (a) When did the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) enter into an agreement with the Australian Ultralight Federation in relation to the administration of sports aviation; and (b) when did that agreement come into effect.
(5) Can a copy of that agreement be provided.

(6) Did that agreement impose conditions on the sports aviation sector in relation to the maintenance of ultralight aircraft; if so (a) what were those conditions; and (b) were they provided in a technical manual that required the approval of CASA; if so, (i) when was the manual approved, and (ii) can a copy be provided.

(7) Since the first sports aviation technical manual was approved: (a) on how many occasions has the manual been amended; (b) when was each amendment made; (c) on each occasion who initiated the amendment; and (d) what was the nature of each amendment.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) (2) and (3) The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) did not enter into a formal agreement with the sports aviation sector in relation to the administration of sports aviation.
The arrangements whereby sports aviation bodies are administered were put in place before the CAA was established.

In August 1983 the Government decided that aviation organisations, which undertook administrative functions on behalf of the Department of Aviation, should be directly funded from Department of Aviation appropriations.

Prior to this decision, the Gliding Federation of Australia and the Royal Federation of Aero Clubs of Australia (amongst others) received a `Grant-in-Aid' from the Government, administered by the Office of the Special Minister of State within the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet.

At various times since 1984, this funding has been reviewed, most notably in 1992 when it was proposed that the payments would be phased out over three years. In 1994, it was agreed that the CAA would continue to contract certain administrative functions to sports administrating bodies.

In 1999, the Board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) agreed that funding would continue to be allocated to sports administering bodies, and reaffirmed its policy of contracting these functions to responsible administering organisations.

The mechanism used to achieve this is an annual contract, whereby each organisation agrees to undertake certain administrative functions on behalf of CASA for which it receives a partial payment of costs incurred, and certain services for which it receives no financial support.
Each funded organisation receives an offer letter with the contract, and is required to account for the previous year's activity.

(4) The Department of Aviation entered into an agreement with the Australian Ultralight Federation (AUF) in relation to the administration of ultralight aircraft in 1984. The agreement came into effect on 5 October 1984.
(5) Yes, a hard copy of the 1984 agreement between the Department of Aviation and the Australian Ultralight Federation has been provided to Senator O'Brien.
(6) I refer to the agreement that has been provided to Senator O'Brien.
(7) The AUF initiates changes to the Manual and seeks CASA's approval.
CASA records do not reveal how many times Issue 1 of the AUF's Technical Manual was provided to the Authority for approval of requested amendments.
Issue 2 of the AUF's Technical Manual was issued in March 1996, and amended (Amendment 1 to Issue 2) in November 1998 (printed in May 1999).

Both Issue 2 and Amendment 1 to Issue 2 were approved by CASA. Issue 2 was an extensive re-write and update of the entire Manual. Amendment 1 to Issue 2 added two new sections: Section 3.3.1 on `Amateur kit-built aircraft registered as Ultralights' and Section 4.1.1 `Criteria for assessment of AUF members for AUF level 2 Maintenance Authorities' to coincide with the introduction of Civil Aviation Regulation (1988) Parts 21-35.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Did the agreement between the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and the sports aviation sector in relation to the administration of sports aviation require the development and approval of an operations manual prior to the agreement coming into effect; if so: (a) when was that operations manual approved by the CAA; and (b) can a copy be provided.

(2) Did the agreement between the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) and the Australian Ultralight Federation in relation to the administration of sports aviation require the development and approval of an operations manual prior to the agreement coming into effect; if so: (a) when was the operations manual approved by CASA; and (b) can a copy of that agreement be provided.

(3) Since the first sports aviation operations manual was approved: (a) on how many occasions has the manual been amended; (b) when was each amendment made; (c) on each occasion who initiated the amendments; and (d) what was the nature of each amendment.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice:
(1) I refer to the answer provided in response to part (1) of Parliamentary Question 28, asked on 13 February 2002.
(2) I refer to the Agreement, a copy of which has been provided to Senator O'Brien.

(3) The Manual has been amended on numerous occasions since 1986. I am advised that on each occasion, the amendments have been initiated by the AUF and approved by CASA or its predecessors. CASA regrets that it is not able to provide a detailed response to this question, in terms of when the amendments were made and what they involved, without a significant expenditure of resources on the search and retrieval of files.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) On how many occasions did the Minister or his staff meet with, or hold a discussion with, the owners, directors or employees of Whyalla Airlines between 1 December 1999 and 31 May 2000.
(2) On each occasion: (a) who attended the meeting, or participated in the discussion; (b) when did the meeting or discussion take place; and (c) where did the meeting or discussion take place.
(3) If any of the above discussions took place by telephone, where were the parties involved in each discussion located.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1), (2) and (3) The Minister and Mr David Kelly of the Minister's Office met with Mr Kym Brougham of Whyalla Airlines in Whyalla on Wednesday the 19th of January 2000. The Member for Grey, Mr Barry Wakelin MP was also present at the meeting.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Did the Minister receive any written, electronic or oral representations on behalf of Mr Chris Brougham or Mr Kym Brougham concerning the appointment of Mr Kym Brougham as acting Chief Pilot, and later Chief Pilot, for Whyalla Airlines between 1 December 1999 and 31 May 2000; if so: (a) when was each representation made; (b) what was the form of the representation; and (c) what was nature of the representation.
(2) (a) When were the above representations responded to; (b) who responded; and (c) what was the nature of the response.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following the answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) There is no record of any such representations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 28 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Bureau of Rural Sciences (BRS) commenced a salinity mapping consultancy as part of the National Action Plan on Salinity and Water Quality; if not, why not and when is the work scheduled to commence; if so (a) where has this work been undertaken to date; and (b) what is the program, by region, to be followed by the BRS in completing this consultancy.
(2) What is the planned timing of the commencement and completion of this work, by state?
(3) (a) What is the value of the contract for salinity mapping consultancy; and (b) who will meet the cost.

(4) If the states are to contribute to the cost of the project: (a) what is the cost to be met by each state; (b) what is the cost to be met by the Commonwealth; and (c) are there agreements in place with each state to meet those costs.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Under the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality, the BRS, in partnership with the CRC for Landscape, Environment and Mineral Exploration and relevant State agencies is carrying out a Salinity Mapping and Management Support Program in:
(5) The Balonne catchment (St George/ Dirrinbandi) in southern Queensland
(7) South Australia (Riverland - 170 000ha, Tintinara - 105 000ha,
(8) Jamestown 76 000ha and Angas-Bremmer 110 000ha).
A proposal to undertake a pilot survey in the Tunbridge area of Tasmania has been approved by the Tasmanian cabinet.

In addition, the BRS is undertaking related salt mapping for the Murray-Darling Basin Commission in the Mid-Broken (SW of Shepparton) in Victoria and Billabong Creek (Culcairn) in NSW. It is intended to incorporate this work into National Action Plan activities.
The Salinity Mapping and Management Support Program is offered to all regions/ States/ Territories that are participating in the National Action Plan.

(2) Negotiations are commencing with each State as soon as bilateral agreements are concluded. Airborne survey of all National Action Plan priority regions could be completed within two years if the States agree to the expenditure and the follow-up analysis and incorporation of this information into regional plans within a further two years. However, the extent and pace of survey is dictated by the States.
Airborne data for the Balonne catchment are already to hand and on-ground calibration is in progress but there is no agreement in place with Queensland to complete the work.
For South Australia, airborne data are scheduled to be delivered between May and July 2002 and final product delivery in December 2003.

(3) (a) The value of the contract depends on the extent to which each State avails itself of the Salinity Mapping and Management Support Program. The cost, up to the stage of incorporating the information into a regional plan, is $6-7/ha for the areas flown with all appropriate airborne systems. About half this cost is for the flying. The cost per hectare can be greatly reduced by extension of this information to the wider region.
The total cost of the work agreed in South Australia is $3.8 million. The cost of flying in Queensland was $2 million.
(b) The cost of salt mapping and management support under the National Action Plan will be met by the Commonwealth and the States on a dollar-for-dollar basis.
(4) (a & b) Division of costs depends on the extent to which each State agrees to use salinity mapping as part of its National Action Plan activities.
(c) Under the National Action Plan, all participating States are expected to sign agreements covering all aspects of their involvement in the Plan, including cost sharing.

subdebateinfo.title: Health and Ageing: Aged Care Assessment Teams
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 156)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 4 March 2002:

quote.para: With reference to Aged Care Assessment Teams (ACAT), can the following details be provided (in a breakdown by state and territory) for 1997-98, 1998-99 and 1999-2000 financial years:
(1) How many ACAT assessments were carried out.
(2) How many individuals were assessed.
(3) What was the average number of assessments for those assessed.
(4) How many ACAT assessments resulted in an assessment that the person required residential high care.
(5) How many ACAT assessments resulted in an assessment that the person required residential low care.
(6) How many ACAT assessments resulted in an assessment that the person required community care in the form of a community aged care package.
(7) How many ACAT assessments resulted in an assessment that the person did not require one of the above forms of care.
(8) How many ACAT assessments took place (identify separately) while the person assessed was in hospital, at home, in a hostel or other location.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Number of ACAT Assessments.
(2) Number of clients assessed.
(3) Average number of assessments for those assessed.
Note: Average number of assessments not available for South Australia due to the unavailability of the number of clients assessed.
(4) Assessments resulting in a residential high care recommendation.
(5) Assessments resulting in a residential low care recommendation.
(6) Assessments resulting in a Community Aged Care Package (CACP) recommendation.
Current data collection systems do not identify CACP recommendations separately. The following data includes recommendations for both CACPs and Community Options Program.
(7) ACAT assessments resulting in an assessment that the person did not require one of the above forms of care.
(8) Location of assessment.
Note: Assessment by location is collected for Hospital and Other only.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Treasury undertaking a review of the Trade Practices Act 1974; if not, why not.

(2) If there is a review being undertaken: (a) has a committee been formed; (b) have submissions been called for; (c) is a discussion paper available to the public; (d) who is on the committee; (e) what are the terms of reference for the review; (f) what is the timetable for the review; and (g) has the review been suspended; if so, at what stage and by whom.
(3) Is the Minister aware of any other reviews of the Act.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) The Government has established an independent Committee. A secretariat is located within the Department of the Treasury.
(2) (a) Yes.

(b) Submissions have been called for in advertisements published nationally on Friday May 24th and Saturday May 25th. Details for lodging a submission can be obtained from the web-site www.TPAreview.treasury.gov.au.
(c) A discussion paper is not currently available to the public.
(d) Sir Daryl Dawson AC KBE CB, former Justice of the High Court, will Chair the Committee. Ms Jillian Segal and Mr Curt Rendall will be the committee members.
(e) The terms of reference were released by the Treasurer on 9 May 2002 in press release number 23.
(f) The Committee will report in November 2002.
(g) No.
(3) The Minister is aware of the current Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee Inquiry into the Trade Practices Act 1974.
The Minister is also aware the Productivity Commission has completed reviews of Parts IIIA, XIB, and XIC of the Act, and is currently reviewing section 2D.

As a result of the recent Commonwealth-State meeting to consider public liability issues, the Minister notes the Commonwealth, States and Territories will examine relevant sections of the Trade Practices Act and comparable State and Territory legislation to consider the extent to which individuals can legally and confidently assume personal responsibility for high risk activities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 April 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the recent call for tenders for a portable sound projection system for the Navy:
(1) (a) How many tenders were submitted; and (b) which organisations submitted tenders.
(2) What was the projected budget for the tender.
(3) Has a decision been made in relation to this tender; if so: (a) which organisation was chosen; and (b) was the tender won on price (ie. all bids met the specifications required).
(4) Has a contract been signed in relation to this purchase.
(5) What is the contracted price for the delivery of the units.
(6) Of the tenders submitted, how many had existing units that could be directly evaluated.
(7) How are tenders assessed against each other and the specifications when some have existing units and others do not.

(8) Did the winning tender have an existing unit to demonstrate its capability against the specifications required; if not, when will the winning tender have a unit available to test against the required specifications.

talk.start.para: —Further to my interim reply, tabled on 17 June 2002, the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) Six. (b) FED I.T. Pty Ltd; Cross Fire Australia Pty Ltd; Goldfields Sound Services; Inwood International Pty Ltd; Operational Solutions Management Pty Ltd; and VAF Research Pty Ltd.
(2) $0.4 million.

(3) Yes. (a) Operational Solutions Management Pty Ltd. (b) the tender was won on a balance of compliance with the Request for Tender's published evaluation criteria, of which price was only one factor.
(4) Yes.
(5) $0.345 million.
(6) Three.

(7) Tenders were individually assessed against the evaluation criteria published in the Request for Tender and then compared against competing tenders. Availability of a pre-existing unit was only one of many factors taken into consideration. Where a tenderer did not have a pre-existing unit, an assessment was made by departmental engineering staff of the tenderer's claims and capability to design and produce the equipment.
(8) No. (a) March 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 18 April 2002:

quote.para: (1) What programs and/or grants administered by the department provide assistance to people living in the federal electorate of Kennedy.
(2) What was the level of funding provided through these programs and/or grants for the 2000-01 and 2001-02 financial years.
(3) Where specific projects were funded: (a) what was the location of each project; (b) what was the nature of each project; and (c) what was the level of funding for each project.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The following table relates to particular grants that are being delivered by my department to the electorate of Kennedy:
2000-01 FINANCIAL YEAR

entry.para: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST AND RELATED FUNDING
Project Officer to administer Riversleigh management committees, provide communication links and manage World Heritage data
Graduate Palaeontologist—Riversleigh Fossils Treatment Laboratory, to provide for scientific research into fossil retrieved from Riversleigh.
Wet Tropics Management Authority Baseline funding
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property
Improved Monitoring (State of the Wet Tropics Reporting)
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property
Phytophthora and Forest Dieback Management Program.
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property*
Tree Revegetation—Trees for the Evelyn Atherton Tablelands (TREAT): Visitor Centre Interactive Display.
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property
Australian Tropical Rainforest World Heritage Area Branding.
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property
Cassowary rehabilitation centres program and rural landholders incentive program.
Covers all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property
Indigenous Protected Area Program (part of the National Reserve System Program)
Lake Moondara Stone Axe Quarry Catchment Management Strategy
Landcare Coordination in North West Queensland
Landcare Coordinator for Southern Gulf catchments.
Riparian Zone Management—Central Upper Burdekin Catchment (NRC)
To improve the biodiversity of the riparian zone over 2.5M ha of the Upper Burdekin Catchment by fencing the double frontage of major watercourses in the area.

The main aim of the project is to fence and revegetate about 1km by 40m of Peterson Creek, removing weeds and noxious trees from the watercourse and creek banks with the ultimate aim of creating a corridor of indigenous trees suitable for improving water quality and maintaining wildlife populations. The area concerned is along the outskirts of Yungaburra township and separates urban development from dairy farming land.

The project aims to demonstrate, and via extension services promote, the integration of cane rodent management and wildlife corridors and strengthen biodiversity corridor links along Walter Hill Ranges to Massey creek in the Johnstone River catchment.
Minimising Soil Loss From Upper Johnstone Grazing Lands

To identify areas, management methods, pasture types and condition and production systems which contribute most to soil loss from the upper catchment. Use results to raise awareness in the farming community and help farmers decide on alternative land, pasture and animal management options on alternative land, pasture and animal management options where needed to achieve ecologically sustainable production systems.

Rehabilitate parts of the riparian system of the Barron River tributary. Major outcomes are the protection of gallery rainforest, the development and enhancement of the riparian corridor to support fauna populations and movement and an improvement in community understanding of the system and the need for its conservation. The development of a rehabilitation plan for the full length of the creek is part of the project. (See 2012017/31694—Mazlin Creek Rehabili-tation Project—Stage 2)
Measuring post-development success of a revegetation project

Monitor previous rehabilitation projects to determine their success: How to measure the success of a revegetation project in terms of ecological change, species selection, species behaviour, planting densities, growth rates, flowering and fruiting. Outcomes from this project are intended to guide future projects.
Implementing the Barron River Integrated Catchment Management Strategy

To effectively and efficiently implement the strategy. To foster and support significant community input. To facilitate the integration of catchment and regional strategy implementation. To plan, monitor and evaluate the progress of projects.

Project manager to manage the implementation of the Johnstone River Catchment Strategy. To support the Johnstone River Catchment Management Authority (JRCMA) Inc., integrate projects evaluate and reassess the Strategy, monitor and manage current projects.
Community Implementation of Regional Strategies Component (G) Management of Sustainable Productivity and Bio Diversity (Tully Flood Plains)
Project officers will support community ownership of projects—essential ingredient in implementation of Ecologically Sustainable Natural Resource Management.
Rehabilitation of threatened Type 5b forest remnants

This project aims to coordinate the recovery of Type 5b forest through the provision of financial assistance/incentives to encourage landholders to implement on ground conservation works to protect and manage remnant 5b fragments and rehabilitate some areas of former 5b forest.
Water Quality Action Plan for Barron River Strategy
The main aim of the project is to implement the Water Quality strategies in the Barron River Catchment Management Strategy.
Application of On-Farm Techniques For Sustaining Aquatic Habitats
The aim is to develop best practice guidelines in farm techniques and alternative measures for sustaining aquatic habitat in the Tully Murray Floodplains.
Riparian and Sub divisional Fencing for Spelling and Revegetation

The main aim is to improve land, pasture and weed management in the upper Gulf and Burdekin catchments to reduce erosion and conserve the natural ecosystems. Better catchment management will be achieved through neighbourly and community cooperation.
Strategic Planning and Implementing Improved Whole Property Management

These on ground works will improve the condition of natural ecosystems and provide management options for sustainable grazing practices. Better catchment management will be achieved through: crisis action in the short term; strategy development; neighbourly cooperation and the development of a cohesive catchment management team.
Managing Native Pastures for Biodiversity and Production
To implement a system of rotational wet season spelling of pastures; to economically rehabilitate native pastures; to demonstrate and monitor mulch induced rehabilitation techniques.
Practical Grazing Management Guidelines for Dalrymple Shire
Practical guidelines to help producers determine pasture condition; safe levels of pasture use; increased awareness and on-ground adoption of sustainable grazing management practices.
Desert Uplands Strategic Land Resource Assessment

To acquire land resource information for the Desert Uplands Designated Area, and can be used to address land management issues at the property level. Develop land management practices. Inform landcare groups and individual landholders of the different land types and the associated limitations and capabilities for current land uses in their area. Establish a GIS database.

This is a spin-off project from the Northern Territory Gouldian Finch Recovery Plan project covering the Queensland components by establishing a Gouldian Regional Operations Group to promote surveys for Gouldian Finches by landholders and volunteers and improve land management in areas where the finches are found to occur.
Sustainable Rangeland Management in the Upper Catchments of Lolworth Creek, Clarke, Basalt and Flinders Rivers

Address these issues—Increasing density of wood plants in the savanna, declining native pasture condition on riparian and black soils areas, prevent the invasion into these areas by exotic woody weeds, soil erosion on riparian and sloping black soil areas, overgrazed areas in large paddocks due to inadequate stock water distribution, adopt land and grazing management practices that are economically viable and will have positive outcomes for biodiversity and conservation.
Mt Fox Catchment and Land Management Skills Development Education and Public Awareness

To provide landholders in the Mt Fox district with the opportunity to further develop their catchment and land management skills. This will be achieved primarily through the presentation of a series of workshops and seminars covering topics relevant to the problem issues to the district. A small-scale catchment plan at the end of the series will be distributed widely in the area. It is suspected that there will be an increase in public awareness of the issues facing the district and strategies for tackling them as a result of these activities.
Development of a Minimum Tillage Planting System for Sugarcane

To use minimum tillage planting technique to reduce soil erosion in the plant crop. A suitable method of plant establishment in the trash remains an important gap of high priority for soil conservation in the whole sugarcane crop cycle. In ratoon crops, a trash blanket effectively protects the soil surface. This project aims to use trash in a minimum tillage planting technique to reduce soil erosion in the plant crop. Three innovative implements will be trialed by an existing Action Learning Group of dedicated growers. The expected outcome of reduced soil erosion will have enormous rural and urban public benefits by contributing to sustainable land-use, river quality, Great Barrier Reef habitat and a healthier environment. With little modification the method should be applicable to sugarcane throughout Australia.
Revegetation of Farm Drains for Sediment Control in the Lower Herbert

The planting of a range of native grasses, shrubs and trees at strategic locations along drains in order to control the movement of sediments, reduce downstream impacts and overcome landholder concerns about vegetation management in drains.
Lagoon Creek Catchment Rehabilitation and Best Management Practices

This project will entail a creek rehabilitation project combined with the adoption of best management practices for surrounding land uses in order to improve water quality, fish habitat and riverine condition in the Lagoon Creek Catchment. An entire catchment approach will be taken by implementing industry best management practices that will improve water quality run off from surrounding land uses in order to maximise the benefits of stream and reparian rehabilitation works. Community involvement, education and ownership will also form part of the project objectives. Finally, the project will also enhance biodiversity by improving connectivity between existing terrestrial and aquatic habitats.

To provide support for the Malanda and Upper Johnstone CLA revegetation project stage 3. This will revegetate riverbank on the Upper Johnstone River. This project provides support for the Malanda & Upper Johnstone Catchment Landcare Associ-ation's (MUJCLA) Upper Johnstone Revegetation Project Stage 3. Together, these two projects will revegetate 9.6 ha of riverbank on the Upper Johnstone River over 2 years. The area targeted is upstream of Malanda's water supply intake which is affected by siltation, in-stream weeds obstructing flow, erosion and slumping banks, and lack of natural riparian vegetation. The work continues on from works undertaken in Stages 1 and 2 of the MUJCLA's Upper Johnstone Revegetation Project which links the area through from Malanda Falls to form a continuous natural riparian zone along the length of the upper Johnstone River. Activities include revegetation, fencing and installation of stock watering points or troughs.

This proposal seeks to continue the rehabilitation activities initiated through Trust funding over the period 1997-99 and is intended to protect a high profile remnant of the endangered Type 5b rainforest held in trust by the Atherton Shire Council. Activities planned include weed eradication, spot planting in degraded areas, surveys to monitor flora and fauna, completion of walking trails and a public awareness program.

Address serious in-stream and riparian degradation adversely affecting water quality in the Upper Johnstone River system above Malanda's water supply intake. Problems targeted will include: siltation, weeds obstructing flow, erosion and slumping of banks, woody weed infestations.
Progressing Northern Bettong Recovery (formerly: Northern Bettong (Bettongia tropica) Recovery Plan implementation, phase 2)

This project was preceded by significant preliminary research into the species that has extensively declined in the eucalypt forests on the western edge of the Wet Tropics Rainforests. A five-year recovery plan for the species was written in conjunction with advice from a broad panel of experts and land managers and primarily focuses on management issues. The most important issues addressed in this stage of the project are determining the distribution of critical food resources and establishing appropriate fire management in the northern bettong habitat.

Project aims to replenish fish stocks to a sustainable level to combat depletions in natural fish stocks caused by recent increase in tourist recreational fishers in Gulf area. This will be done by spawning, growing out and tagging grunter fingerlings bred at our established hatchery in Kurumba before releasing them at sites selected by QDPI. Done over a 3 year period this will enable the new bag and size limits to come into effect which will maintain fish stocks.
Addressing External Threats to the Ecosystems and Biodiversity of the Gulf Region

Recent strategic planning papers have identified two threats to the biodiversity of the Gulf Region. These threats are an increased number of tourists and new exotic weed invasions. This project will establish a “community owned” structure that mitigates threats to the biodiversity of the region. This will be achieved in two ways: 1. Provide better facilities for tourists so that their activities do not degrade sensitive ecosystems. 2. Prevent new exotic weeds establishing. Local Government Authorities will ensure the successful completion of this project by providing infrastructure, leadership and legislative power.

The project is to implement actions in the Draft Recovery plan for the Julia Creek Dunnart that is scheduled to run for 5 years (2000 to 2004) and is designed to engage and build community capacity to identify, protect and manage key sites for the Julia Creek Dunnart, in a landscape supporting sustainable agricultural production.
Community Implementation of the Herbert River Catchment Strategy

Seminars on resource management issues to raise community and industry awareness. Planning exercises. Support for community and local government projects. Co-ordinate existing extension effort in the catchment.

Strengthen and consolidate vegetated areas along Peterson Creek, by linking existing `stepping stones' of native vegetation to form a continuous wildlife corridor between Lake Eacham National Park & Yungaburra State Forest. (See 2012028/31706 [g1]—Peterson Creek Corridor Consolidation—Stage 2)
Strategic rehabilitation and reinstatement of wetland vegetation in a number of priority sites in the Johnstone Catchment by a partnership of regional community groups.
Conservation of remnant vegetation on private property on the Atherton Tablelands

Promote the conservation and restoration of remnant vegetation and wildlife habitat to private landholders on the Atherton Tablelands through the development and implementation of wildlife management habitat plans.
Strategic Revegetation of Mazlin Creek to address community and ecological needs
Stabilise and revegetate strategic sites on the Mazlin Creek to filter sediment and nutrients and assist in creating continuous native vegetation cover along the creek
Stage 1 Restoration of Towers Hill, Charters Towers
Develop and implement an integrated management program for the flora, fauna and historical integrity of Towers Hill, Charters Towers
Promote best management practices for land management in the Northern Gulf through one on one extension and an adaptive management program, in conjunction with a revolving loan fund.
Wanamara and Richmond Community Bush Tucker Project

Provide focus for sector of the community, in particular the Wanamara people and members of Richmond State School, to work towards a common goal and build relationships within the community. This project will address NRM issues relative to the Richmond district, delivering education and raising awareness amongst youth and the wider community of those issues, and at the same time promoting indigenous culture with particular regard to bush tucker and medicine and land management practices.
Advancing On ground Nature Conservation in the Southern Gulf Regions

To protect, restore and encourage appropriate manage-ment of high priority native vegetation communities in the Southern Gulf region through the provision of an incentive scheme. The focus of the project will be on protecting and/or expanding key flora and fauna habitat that has been identified as Endangered or Of Concern. Works will be guaranteed through Voluntary Management Agreements and the project will create demonstration sites and raise community awareness of the value of nature conservation as a land management tool.
Accelerated Community Based NRM Outcomes in the Wet Tropics Region

Assist the community in implementing priority compo-nents of the Wet Tropics Regional Strategy for Natural Resource Management, through a four monthly rolling schedule of individual project applications
Co-ordination, Sustainable Farming Systems Projects and Revegetation Programs

This project incorporates the services of a part-time Coordinator into a wide range of projects and activities being undertaken by two (2) Landcare groups (`Malanda and Upper Johnstone Catchment Landcare Association' (MUJCLA) and `North Johnstone and Lake Eacham Landcare Association' (NJLELA)) operating on the Southern Atherton Tableland. It will assist the groups to achieve their revegetation objectives in the Upper Johnstone River system including tree planting targets of 30,000 trees by September 2001 and satisfactory maintenance of areas already planted with 70,000 trees. It will also assist the implementation of a suite of five (5) projects which are contributing to the development of sustainable farming systems for the area. An important long-term aim is to improve the ability of these groups to identify problems, plan and implement projects, and to evaluate, report and extend results.
Community Access Natural Resource Management Database for the Wet Tropics Region
Establishment of a community access regional database and Geographic Information System (GIS) layer of current & completed natural resource management projects in the Wet Tropics Region.
Wet Tropics NHT Regional Strategy Group Coordination
Further the implementation of the Wet Tropics Regional Strategy for Natural Resource Management in the current Natural Heritage Trust (NHT) system and beyond.
Producers Implementing Sustainable Grazing and Weed Control to Protect the Gulf Catchment
Improve the condition of the natural ecosystems on the Dry River and provide a weed protection buffer between the Burdekin and Gulf catchments.
Better Grazing Distribution in the Balfes Creek Catchment using Mine Tyres as Water Troughs
Installation of additional watering points in the Balfes Creek catchment to reduce patch overgrazing/ degradation and even out grazing pressure, using recycled mine truck tyres as water troughs.
Northern Gulf Regional Strategy—Bioregional Coordinator, Business Development and Communication
Further advance the status of the Northern Gulf Regional Strategy Plan through the development of a business plan and communication plan and continued implementation, monitoring and review.

Develop forestry plantations, research and monitor programs and economic strategies to investigate the potential of sewerage effluent plantations in arid North West Queensland (Focusing on native species). The project will investigate different species, products, technologies and markets to stimulate a sustainable, environmentally friendly industry in Northern Australia.
Re-establishment of Riparian Vegetation, Gregory River

The aim of this project is to provide a demonstration to landholders of best practice techniques for re-establishing riparian vegetation on riverbanks grazed by livestocks. A trial 10 kilometre section of the Gregory River will be fenced off to limit access to livestock. Natural regeneration will then follow in addition to seeding of sections of the riverbank to allow comparison between regenerating areas. Monitoring programs will be used to track changes in vegetation and water quality. An extensive and ongoing public awareness and education program will be initiated to disseminate information to local landholders.
Accelerated Community Based NRM Outcomes in the Wet Tropics Region

Assist the community in implementing priority components of the Wet Tropics Regional Strategy for Natural Resource Management, through a four monthly rolling schedule of individual project applications.
Restoring the Ripar-ian and Aquatic Habitats Along Swee-ney Creek-An Urban Waterway
Restoration of the riparian and in stream habitats of Sweeney Creek to encourage the return of natural aquatic flora and fauna species.
Strategic Plan for the Restoration of the Mulgrave River
Development of a strategic plan and program of river restoration works for the Mulgrave River catchment.
Construction of an artificial wetland in Palm Creek Ingham for urban storm water management.

Project aims to establish monitoring systems for feral pig populations and resultant impact in sugarcane/banana-growing areas of north Qld. This information will allow derivation of density: damage relationships which can be used to develop performance indicators for north Qld and other feral pig management programs. This information is essential to allow landholders and government agencies to determine the most cost-effective level of feral pig control—i.e. the point where control costs and subsequent damage mitigation are optimised.

Flinders Shire Council seeks funding:- to repair the riparian zone of the Hughenden Reach of the Flinders River which is highly degraded through erosion—encourage native fauna back to the zone through maintenance and development of wildlife corridors—educate the community on the conservation process—to promote broad community awareness, co-operation and involvement in the project.
Best Practice Riparian Management and Enhancement for Tully River and Tributaries

Rehabilitation of priority sites within the Tully River and its tributaries using revegetation and engineering works, and conduction of a public awareness program on best practice creek bank protection for landholders.
Assessment of Eacham Shire's Natural Assets for Sustainable Land Management

Collation of existing natural resource management and vegetation information in the Eacham Shire for incorporation into a decision support system for sustainable development, land management and biodiversity conservation.
Producers Implementing Sustainable Grazing to Improve Natural Ecosystems

This project aims to improve the condition of the natural ecosystems on a continuous group of twenty properties covering 576,977ha of the Towerhill and Torrens Creek catchments. This area is part of Lake Eyre catchment and will achieve the above aim by fencing watercourses, installing alternative watering points, strategic woody weed control in riparian areas and fencing to grazing capability. Implementing these sustainable grazing practices will produce substantial public benefit through long-term community commitment, environmental and economic benefits.
Coastcare Program—Stabilisation and Rehabilitation of Rollingstone Creek, Balgal

Unrestricted access to all areas of the riverbank has caused total depletion of the native vegetation. The wet season of 1999-00 was particularly severe and caused deep scouring of the bank leading to a scarp developing and causing more problems. This removed the remaining vegetation. This project will install fencing to eliminate public access to the re-vegetation areas, will define access to the beach and creek by using sand ladders. The project will establish a water line and drippers to ensure sustainable growth and quicker stabilisation of the site. Interpretation signage will be erected to: 1. Advise people of planting works, what and who is doing the work. 2. To educate the public about riparian vegetation. 3. To promote Coastcare involvement in and support for the project.
Coastcare Program—Community Sea Turtle Conservation in the Townsville Coastal Region

Sea turtles in Queensland are under increasing threat from human impacts. Within the Townsville region there is a distinct lack of data on levels of nesting of the flatback and green turtle species (both classified as vulnerable under Federal legislation).
