Assist the community in implementing priority components of the Wet Tropics Regional Strategy for Natural Resource Management, through a four monthly rolling schedule of individual project applications.
Restoring the Riparian and Aquatic Habitats Along Sweeney Creek-An Urban Waterway
Restoration of the riparian and in stream habitats of Sweeney Creek to encourage the return of natural aquatic flora and fauna species.

Flinders Shire Council seeks funding:- to repair the riparian zone of the Hughenden Reach of the Flinders River which is highly degraded through erosion—encourage native fauna back to the zone through maintenance and development of wildlife corridors—educate the community on the conservation process—to promote broad community awareness, co-operation and involvement in the project.
Best Practice Riparian Management and Enhancement for Tully River and Tributaries

Rehabilitation of priority sites within the Tully River and its tributaries using revegetation and engineering works, and conduction of a public awareness program on best practice creek bank protection for landholders.
Producers Implementing Sustainable Grazing to Improve Natural Ecosystems

This project aims to improve the condition of the natural ecosystems on a continuous group of twenty properties covering 576,977ha of the Towerhill and Torrens Creek catchments. This area is part of Lake Eyre catchment and will achieve the above aim by fencing watercourses, installing alternative watering points, strategic woody weed control in riparian areas and fencing to grazing capability. Implementing these sustainable grazing practices will produce substantial public benefit through long-term community commitment, environmental and economic benefits.
The Townsville Southbank Coastal Acid Sulfate Soil Remediation Project

This project will use wastewater to demonstrate a means of reducing acid and heavy metal runoff from 12 highly acidified, abandoned, aquaculture ponds on some 50 hectares of the south bank of the Ross River at Townsville. A range of neutralising materials and techniques will be employed to create an innovative fresh and saltwater wetland filtering system. The pond walls will be neutralised by mixing the top half with agricultural lime and the bottom half using a technique from another CASSP funded project, lime slotting. Once construction is completed, the top ponds will receive freshwater from a waste water treatment plant. This water will flow through the wetland system to the bottom 4 ponds which will have buffering capacity as a result of tidal exchange.

To build the capacity of private farm forestry sector in North Queensland to deliver commercial services to farmers and to ensure training needs are met to an accredited standard. Achievement of this objective in the region will help facilitate the transition from government-funded programs towards industry and community driven projects. A phased transition is required in North Queensland due to the current fledgling and fragmented nature of the current resource. A report will be produced at the end of the Natural Heritage Trust funding to determine the success of the project and recommend future directions for the growing of the farm forestry industry.
Restoration of High Priority Habitats in the Townsville Thuringowa Region

The project will focus on the protection, rehabilitation (including revegetation) and management of areas identified as having high conservation significance in local and regional strategies. It will further enhance community ownership and participation in environmental projects and consolidate partnerships between government, local business and the community. The project will promote community awareness of the benefits of conserving native vegetation through Bushcare activities and the development of educational materials.
Managing the Environmentally Sensitive Areas in the Headwaters District

The Headwaters Landcare Group consists of 11 North Queensland cattle properties covering an area of 406,250 hectares of open savanna grazing lands on basaltic and sandy soils. The project aims to better manage the environmentally sensitive areas by fencing to control access by livestock. These areas include: 1. Basalt springs, lakes and soaks; 2. Riparian areas on major watercourses; 3. Black soil areas favoured by livestock; 4. Soft wood scrubs. The changes in vegetation (pastures and woody weeds) and water quality will be monitored to evaluate the success of the project.
Management of the Birdbush Basalt Environment and Grazing Industry

The Birdbush Basalt district is one of the most viable beef producing areas in the Burdekin Rangelands. It has a unique blend of basaltic soils, geological formations including the Great Basalt Wall National Park and spring-fed streams. Although the natural resources of the area are in good condition, there are some threats that Natural Heritage trust funding can help to overcome. They include declining pasture condition, overgrazed/weedy stream frontages, scalded land and declining water quality. This project aims to use fencing to regulate grazing pressures on stream frontages and other favoured areas. So that vegetation in riparian areas can regenerate and water quality can improve.
Sustained Pasture Management through Development of Strategic Waterpoints in the Upper Haughton Catchment

The project proposes development of strategic water points away from the river to enable control of stock grazing along the Upper Haughton River and tributaries, and prevent erosion, run-off and subsequent sediment problems from trampled cattle pads near the river. Development of reticulated water points will better the uneven grazing pressure and native pasture decline; loss of biodiversity and degradation of riparian areas; the invasion and impact of woody weeds; the impact of past grazing management practices on pasture condition and ground cover.
Protection of Ravenswood District Riparian Areas, Remnant Softwood Scrubs and Heritage Sites

The project will involve a cooperative effort from 20 district landholders to use riparian fencing to control grazing pressure and limit the impact of stock on these ecosystems; carefully place additional water ways from these riparian areas to reduce grazing pressure on major watercourses; assess and protect local mining heritage sites which may improve the eco-tourism appeal of our district; revegetate severely degraded areas through stock exclusion and mechanical treatment (ie ripping, seeding and weed control). The project objectives compliment the on-ground works funded by the catchment protection project (1999/2000) and the Drought Regional Initiative infrastructure projects in 97/98.

An area of about 10 hectares along 5 km of the upper reaches of the Barron River has become badly degraded although there are significant remnants of the natural riverine forests remaining (5(b) North Queensland “Mabi” tropical rainforest) remaining. As a start of a long-term programme to link riverine forest remnants, help prevent riverbank erosion and improve water quality, TREAT will collect local tree seed, clear weeds, raise seedlings, revegetate about 2 ha and maintain and monitor planted areas.
Upper Johnstone Revegetation Project Stage 3 Extension

Proven rainforest revegetation methods will be used to address serious in-stream and riparian degradation affecting water quality, ecological processes and biodiversity in the Upper Johnstone River system. Problems targeted include siltation, in-stream weeds, erosion, slumping of banks and woody weed infestations. Planned activities include site preparation, 2.6 kilometres of fencing, planting 15,000 trees along 3 kilometres of watercourse, construction of 2 water access points and a crossing for stock, and raising public awareness of the problems and rehabilitation measures required. This extension to Stage 3 of the existing project will create a vital linkage between the 10 kilometres of tributaries already planted and a 28 hectares patch of isolated remnant rainforest upstream form the current planted boundary.
Implementation of the Herbert River Catchment Management Strategy

Continue to implement the Herbert River Catchment Management Strategy by building partnerships with community groups to develop and manage collaborative projects that address the priority issues within the Catchment. Foster close collaboration and communication with local and State government to develop a collective approach to priority Catchment issues. Advance community education and awareness of Catchment issues. Implement new projects within the Catchment. Ensure successful and continuing preservation of rehabilitation systems.

The TYTO Wetlands project sets out to provide an educational resource for the local community, educational institutions, tourists and landholders in promoting the environmental significance of wetland areas. A major importance of the project is that it aims to conserve an ecosystem that is classified as Endangered and contains many wildlife inhabitants including owls and finches which are under threat species. The project aims to restore and preserve the existing degraded wetland at Ingham. This restoration work involves control of introduced weed species and replanting of naturally occurring vegetation.
Key Habitat Connectivity in the Cardwell Shire

The project is focused on protecting and enhancing remnant vegetation on private land within the Cardwell Shire on the Tully/Murray floodplain. Opportunities to maintain connectivity between the protected areas and between the coastal strip and the ranges to the west are rapidly disappearing. This project seeks to reduce the impacts of fragmentation by identifying, protecting and where necessary, restoring broad connectivity. Activities will include initial identification and prioritization of remnants, negotiations with landholders to put in place voluntary conservation agreements and revegetation works and education to include the community.

The project Manager position is crucial in ensuring that effective natural resource management in the Johnstone River Catchment continues to be implemented, whilst retaining economic activity. In the past, this position has demonstrated what a community group can accomplish with the assistance of a full-time employee. The project Manager performs many roles in implementing the Johnstone River Catchment Strategy and is responsible for developing funding applications, managing projects and co-ordinating community activities for the Catchment Association and Landcare group. One of the most important roles for the Project Manager is to increase the awareness and involvement within the community in managing our natural resources, and to strengthen linkages between key stakeholders in NRM.
Accelerated Community Based NRM Outcomes in the Wet Tropics—Component 2

This devolved grant project aims to assist the community in implementing priority components of the Wet Tropics Regional Strategy for Natural Resource Management. The community will be invited to submit project applications, seeking up to $10 000, addressing priorities focused on the eight programs under the Wet Tropics Regional Strategy: 1—Vegetation, 2-Wildlife, 3-Water, Waterways and Wetlands, 4-Coastal and Marine Resources, 5-Sustained Primary Industries, 6- Pest plants and Animals, 7-Waste and Pollution, 8-Implementation. The Strategy was formally endorsed by the Queensland Landcare and Catchment Management Council in August 1998 and reviewed in September 1999. The project has been funded at $200 000 per year over 2 years under the Landcare and Bushcare programs, and as such has limited scope to address priority issues aligned with Rivercare priorities. This component of the project seeks to fund projects focused on Rivercare priorities under the same conditions as the original approved project, WT 2002.
Water Quality Assessment for Sustainable Agriculture

This project will establish a pilot water quality monitoring system that engages landholders in assessing their impacts on water quality. It will provide a mechanism for evaluating the effectiveness of best management practices for the major industries of sugarcane, banana and broad acre farming in the Wet Tropics. Although it has a significant scientific content due to the nature of the problem being addressed, it is NOT a research project and focuses strongly on facilitating on ground changes to farm management practices.
Implementation of the Russell Mulgrave Catchments Strategy

1. Implementation of the Russel Mulgrave Catchment strategy, and the Mulgrave River action plan currently being done by the RIT. 2. Managing and Facilitating Best Management Practices in sugarcane through the Mulgrave mill grower groups in the Mulgrave catchment mill area. 3. Addressing conflicts with riverine management. 4. On-going review of the strategic plan.

Mazlin Ck is a primary stream in the Upper Barron/ Tinaroo catchment, and the condition of its riparian vegetation and water quality has been a concern to natural resource managers for many years. Original habitat along the creek is sparse and pest weeds and rats pose a major problem to farmers in the area. In the recent past, NHT funds for projects on this system have made huge in-roads to rehabilitation (TREAT, Barron River Integrated Catchment Management Assn, Atherton Shire WTTPS). This application will incorporate a seed dispersal/ recruitment trial within the ongoing rehabilitation project to establish the role played by Spectacled Flying Foxes (a local vulnerable species) in forest regeneration here. The work of TREAT Project (No 982017) in the mid reaches of the creek, will be consolidated and extended to give greater coverage of endangered Type 5b forest species, better connections of riparian vegetation and remnants (including other revegetation work in the upper and lower reaches of the creek), exo.
Co-ordinate the Implementation of the Barron River Integrated Catch-ment Management Strategy

This project supports the implementation of the Barron River Integrated Catchment Management (ICM) Strategy to improve the health and well being of the Barron Catchment. It will address identified priorities by: 1) Co-ordinating committee activities and needs for the Barron River Integrated Catchment Management Association to maintain ongoing action; 2) Implementing priority strategy goals—namely water quality and land use management; 3) Raising awareness of ICM through community involvement in on-ground projects; 4) Providing a wide variety of ICM education and extension opportunities; and 5) Developing and promoting landscape frameworks to strategically manage conservation, land and water values (incorporating farm, local government, catchment and regional management plans).

Revegetation of 1.150 kilometres (3 hectares) of cleared and eroding river bank with green engineering (9,000 seedlings), linking existing revegetation and Johnstone River Improvement Trust project sites, restoring a wildlife corridor and riparian buffer between World Heritage area and the Basilisk Range. This is a strategic approach to riverine restoration providing erosion control in the upper reaches of the South Johnstone River, consequently reducing sediment loading and in turn improving water quality and stream habitat.

This project aims to carry out 12 ha of on ground works through a sustainable partnership between community and local government, by integrating assisted natural regeneration and supplementary planting of tube stock in priority areas where works have not been previously carried out. Address remaining impediments to community vegetation management though coordination of resources & improved community technical skills, awareness and participation in this area. Impose a scale of landholder contributions where income will be generated to offset the cost of environmental repair. Development of management agreements to ensure long-term maintenance. Integration with Conservation Covenant and Land for Wildlife Schemes.
Cancy Estate Wetland Remnant Rehabilitation Project

This project aims to protect and rehabilitate 30 hectares of remnant inland swamp vegetation (covering three Endangered Regional Ecosystem types) in the Innisfail Cassowary Management Area, threatened by exotic species and clearing. Wetlands in upper Ninds Ck area listed as significant in “ Directory of Important Wetlands In Australia”. Assisted natural regeneration through strategic weed control and supplementary planting of tube stock will enhance connectivity between the remnant and the Moresby Ranges through the Ninds Creek catchment. The area is to be preserved in perpetuity through a Voluntary Conservation Agreement and will be maintained as a nature reserve and facility for conservation and scientific studies.
North Johnstone River Stabilisation and Riparian Vegetation Reinstatement

Serious in-stream erosion caused by over clearing is affecting the viability of natural stream functions. Problems include siltation, weed infestation, erosion, and slumping riverbanks, which are all due to the lack of natural riparian vegetation. Fragmentation of the riparian zone has also created discontinuities of riparian habitat, which is a significant resource area for rare and threatened wildlife. Objectives include: 1) On-ground works consisting of 4 ha {2 ha of revegetation, 2 ha management of remnant vegetation} by assisting natural regeneration and supplementary planting. 8,000 seedlings total on road reserve adjacent to North Johnstone River. 2) Restore the East-West vegetation linkages through the flood plain with the aim to link conservation areas in the long term. 3) Eradicate weed infestations through permanent site capture. 4) Raise awareness and technical expertise through demonstration to facilitate self-sufficiency of continuing works. Assessment of works resulting from demonstration.
Adopt and Restore the Macknade Wetland

This is a community-based project that aims to adopt an existing degraded wetland that is invaded by paragrass and other weeds and rehabilitate it so that it will support a diversity of native plant, bird and fish life, and be self-sustaining in the long term. Wetland degradation resulted from past milling practices and landuse, which have now been replaced with more sustainable practices that no longer impact upon the Wetland. The project will: 1. Remove the paragrass and other aquatic weeds; construct an island to act as a bird refuge; widen the eastern bank of the wetland; and revegetate the island and eastern bank. 2. Involve the community, landholders, industry and local school children and demonstrate the importance of wetland communities. 3. Increase the capacity of the community to manage and rehabilitate areas of high conservation value within the Lower Herbert River Catchment. 4. Provide an opportunity to promote the values of wetlands in the Catchment as the site's proximity to the main road provides high interpretation and promotional value.
Upper North Johnstone River Revegetation Project

As a start to a long term program to link riverine forest remnants, help prevent river-bank erosion and improve water quality TREAT will work with Eacham Shire Council to collect local tree seed, clear weeds, raise seedlings and revegetate about 2 ha of a badly degraded section of the North Johnstone River, part of which runs through Malanda town. Only fragmented remnants of the natural riverine forest remain (5(b) North Queensland “Mabi” tropical rainforest.

This project seeks to strengthen and consolidate vegetated areas along Peterson Creek by linking existing “stepping stones” of native vegetation to form a continuous wildlife corridor between Lake Eacham National Park and Yungaburra State Forest. Stepping-stones were initially created in the knowledge that a fully vegetated corridor was not possible in the initial 3 year NHT funding cycle. The consolidation and linkage of these stepping-stones in the logical second but vital stage in this important project. The project covers about 10 ha along 5 km of creek bank. In addition to providing a wildlife corridor between two isolated and endangered forest remnants, outcomes include protection of creek banks from erosion, reduced sediment, improved water quality and an increased community awareness of the need for healthy riparian ecosystems.
Rationalisation of Dalrymple Land Resource Data

The proposed project wishes to utilise the Dalrymple dataset and generate user friendly maps of the different land types, with accompanying descriptions of the limitations and capabilities for different land uses, a risk analysis for erosion, salinity and other land degradation processes, and recommended management practices for sustainable land use, thereby completing a large gap in the Desert Uplands land resource database.
On-ground Works for Native Vegetation Management and Rehabilitation (Devolved Grant)

The aim of this project is to provide financial and other assistance to landholders for strategic on ground works to protect and better manage priority areas of native vegetation in the Einasleigh Uplands bioregion and Northern Gulf.

The project will rehabilitate degraded country in the environs of Georgetown. Overgrazing of the Georgetown common has resulted in increased woody seed species, native timber thickening and erosion of the riparian zones on Etheridge River and Sandy Creek. The Georgetown Progress Association, Etheridge Shire Council and town residents will rehabilitate these areas by replacing exotic woody weed species with native endemic tree species and stabilising the banks of the waterways with grasses. Illegally dumped rubbish will be removed and a path will be maintained around the town and along the riverbank for use by locals and visitors. The project will be promoted by prominent signage on the highway and through radio and media releases.
Wyvuri Swamp Esplanade Hymenachne Control/Eradication Program

This project aims to find and chemically treat all areas of Hymenachne in the Wyvuri Swamp Esplanade; undertake follow up monitoring and treatment for any reappearance of Hymenachne in the area; Stop the spread of Hymenachne down the Wyvuri Swamp Esplanade/Frenchman's Creek to the Russell River. The long-term goal is the eradication of Hymenachne from the Wyvuri Swamp Esplanade.
Hymenachne control in the Cardwell Shire (Far North Queensland)

This project aims to control Hymenachne on all shire lands by implementing an integrated, effective long-term control program by: Making an application for a Minor Use Permit to use “Verdict” in areas where the weed is present in water; undertaking detailed mapping of infestations to prioritise works; optimising the on ground works by councils pest management team; Improving public awareness of the weed through education programs; linking with other stakeholders to strategically revegetate some areas previously infested with Hymenachne.
Adaptive Management: Pond Apple control in the catchments of the Russell-Mulgrave and Tully-Murray River Systems

Control all known outbreaks of Pond Apple in the 4 river catchments, in particular those infestations in flood prone areas, which act as a seed bank to reinfect previously treated areas; Survey all know outbreaks in the 4 catchments, update the existing mapping of known outbreaks using GPS, identify new areas of outbreak and control small outbreaks as they are found by using adaptive management techniques. Large infestations in the Russell Mulgrave, and Tully Murray catchments will be controlled after the cessation of the wet season; Monitor previously controlled areas to ensure reinfestation has not occurred; Treat any new pond apple outbreaks; Prepare revegetation plans for areas where necessary; Prepare management plan for ongoing future management of pond apple.
Utilising revegetation to shade out Hymenachne

To revegetate sites where hymenachne control works have been undertaken and reestablish natural ecosystems. To determine the effectiveness of revegetation in controlling hymenachne infestations, preventing hymenachne regeneration and reducing the invasion of hymenachne.
Coastcare Program—Southern end Lucinda Beach Revegetation and Fencing Project

Accelerated erosion of sand dune system which needs stabilizing. We propose to fence a designated area of foreshore to restrict 4WD and pedestrian access. Revegetate this area to slow down wind erosion. Maintain the total area by controlling weeds. Enhance area by improving access to coast with designated walkways for pedestrians. Outcomes include an area for safe pedestrian access with a stabilized dune system restored with native vegetation.
Coastcare Program—South Mission Beach Coastcare Project

This project seeks to build on a previous Coastcare project and in addition use the outcomes of a planning process that will be carried out later this year involving State Agencies, Local Government and community to address issues for foreshore degradation at South Mission Beach. Specifically, the project will look at rehabilitation 0.2 ha over two sections of the SMB foreshore by removing weed, revegetating with appropriate species and providing beach access. Most importantly in-depth signage will explain the project and provide the community with detailed knowledge of coastal and dunal ecological processes.

Implement Coastcare Regional priority to rehabilitate Cowley Beach foreshore along north arm of Liverpool Creek including management of vehicle access to southern end of the spit to protect dune vegetation and shorebird roosting. Bollards to restrict access to disorderly vehicular and pedestrian traffic. Adjoins Liverpool Creek section of Coastal Wildlife Corridor. Critical Cassowary habitat. Priority management area for public access. Priority area for weed management. Management of natural regeneration and revegetation to restore habitat and reinstate vegetation linkage. 3ha on ground works. Education/ awareness through interpretive signage and community participation. 160m bollards/vehicular barrier.
Coastcare Program—Forrest Beach Fern Street Rehabilitation

The degraded frontal dune needs rehabilitating, and treatments to ensure erosion doesn't continue. Fencing out vehicles, constructing and managing access tracks and revegetation works, comprise the project
Ballast Water Mitigation Program—The Australian Pilot Project for Treatment of Ships' Ballast Water

The project will assemble an operational pilot plant to remove harmful organisms from ballast water. The plant will be portable and moved by truck to operate under the widely varied conditions of several Australian ports. If successful, the technology could be installed on ships.
Coastcare Program—Coastal Cassowary Information Signage along Wet Tropics Coast
Coastal forest habitat on the lowlands of the wet tropics has been extensively cleared and fragmented. Over 70% of lowland habitat has been lost between Cairns and Townsville.
National Wetlands Program—Cooperative Wetland Management Agreements in Outback Australia Stage 2

This project will see the establishment of a range of cooperative management agreements covering approximately 200 000 ha of significant wetlands on private land in Outback Queensland. Wetlands from these areas have been under represented in the reserve system, the Ramsar List and off reserve conservation programs and agreements. The project will facilitate works at selected sites. The project builds on the initiatives of the Outback Wetlands Project Stage One and will see the adoption of a range of additional agreements addressing the management of significant wetlands in Outback Queensland and will further expand the network of significant wetlands subject to management agreements. This project will raise awareness and understanding of wetland values and promote successful case studies of wetlands protection and management agreements. It also promotes Ramsar listing as one option for the establishment of agreements for the wise use of nationally important wetlands.

quote.para: * This payment potentially covers work over all of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage property including those parts in the electorate of Leichhardt as well as those parts in the electorate of Kennedy. It is not possible separate the amount between these electorates.

NB: Under the GLOBE Australia Program, the Department has provided in-kind support to two schools within the electorate of Kennedy (Doomadgee State School and Yungaburra State School). It no longer provides funding under the program. The in-kind support entailed teacher professional development workshops during 1997-2001 and the on-going provision of program materials and resources. The GLOBE Australia Program was jointly funded through the Department of the Environment and Heritage and the Department of Education, Science and Training during the period 1997-2001 to the value of $50,000 each per annum. Although the program no longer receives Commonwealth funding, the Department of the Environment and Heritage continues to provide in-kind support to participating Australian schools.

NB: The ChemCollect program, which is co funded by the Commonwealth and the States up to $27 million, provides a national scheme for collection of unwanted agricultural and veterinary checmicals from farms. There may have been some expenditure in the electorate of Kennedy, however, due to the nature of the program, funding within particular electorates cannot be identified.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 April 2002:

quote.para: With reference to page 25 of the Defence portfolio additional estimates statements 2001-02, which lists a number of cancelled exercises: in relation to each of these exercises separately, can the following information be provided: (a) what the total cost of the exercise would have been, including embedded costs, eg. salaries; (b) what the total additional cost of the exercise would have been, excluding embedded costs that would have accrued without the exercise, eg. allowances that are paid while on exercise, higher fuel usage; (c) a breakdown of the additional costs associated with the exercise, eg. allowances, fuel, ammunition, equipment replacement, maintenance; and (d) how many personnel would have participated in the exercise, its duration and a description of the activities the personnel would have been performing.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Question sought information relating to the budgeted cost of various Australian Defence Force (ADF) exercises listed in the Parliamentary Additional Estimates 2001-2002 as having been cancelled as at the publication of the document.

The question calls for an excessive amount of detail which I do not intend to provide. Major exercises that have been cancelled, postponed or modified as a result of the increased operation tempo include:

answer.para: · 11 anti-submarine warfare exercises;
· 2 Army helicopter training exercises;
· 4 RAN surface warfare capability exercises;
· 3 minor Army exercises;
· 1 amphibious capability exercise;
· 1 airdrop exercise and competition; and
· 1 Navy clearance diving exercise.

quote.para: The program of Defence exercises is designed to keep the ADF at the level of preparedness required of it by the Government. This is achieved within the level of funds provided to Defence and subsequently distributed to the Service Chiefs, consistent with the particular requirements of their respective combat forces. Where an activity is cancelled, a substitute activity or requirement would take its place, either in the form of another similar activity, or as is often the case, a sequence of many smaller and less identifiable activities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 April 2002:

quote.para: With reference to pages 26 to 29 of the Defence portfolio additional estimates statements 2001-02, which lists exercises that will occur during the 2001-02 financial year: in relation to each of these exercises separately, can the following information be provided: (a) the total budget for the exercises (please confirm that this is an additional cost, i.e. does not included ongoing costs that would have accrued without the exercise); (b) if the exercise has been completed, the actual cost of the exercise (if this varies from the budget for the exercise explain the reason for the discrepancy); (c) if the budget for the exercise has been revised, the revised budget and the reason for the change; (d) a breakdown of the budget for the exercise, eg. allowances, fuel, ammunition, equipment replacement, maintenance; and (e) how many personnel will be involved in the exercise, its duration and a description of the activities the personnel will be performing.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: There is no additional cost in conducting the exercises identified. The program of Defence exercises is designed to keep the Australian Defence Force at the level of preparedness required of it by the Government. This is achieved within the level of funds provided to Defence and subsequently distributed to the Service Chiefs, consistent with the particular requirements of their respective combat forces.

The exercises listed in the pages 26 - 29 of the Defence Portfolio Additional Estimates Statements 2001-02 represent only some of the activities the combat forces undertake as part of generating their required level of preparedness. If one of the identified activities were to be cancelled, a substitute activity would take its place, either in the form of another similar exercise, or as is often the case, a sequence of many smaller and less identifiable activities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 May 2002:

question.para: With reference to Australian citizen David Hicks, currently a prisoner of the United States (US):

(1) Have Mr Hicks' rights, including his legal rights, been upheld while in US custody in the same way they would have been upheld in Australia; if not, in what way has the US custody abrogated the equivalent Australian rights or expectations.
(2) What representations has the Minister made to the US Government about Mr Hicks' rights and when (please specify).

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Mr Hicks is being held in US custody under President Bush's Military Order dealing with the Detention, Treatment and Trial of Non-US Citizens in the War Against Terrorism. Therefore his treatment is a matter for US authorities in accordance with US domestic law and international law as set out in international instruments to which the US is a party.

Mr Hicks was captured in a conflict zone by the Northern Alliance and is being detained in US military custody. Investigations into Mr Hicks' activities are continuing. This is not a routine police investigation, where a crime has been committed and the purpose of the investigation is to find the person who committed the offence and gather supporting evidence within Australia or the US. The current investigation is focused on determining whether Mr Hicks has committed any offence, not within Australia or the US, but within a war zone where there is no easy access to possible witnesses and next to no supporting infrastructure.

The US has indicated that the detainees are being held as a consequence of their alleged links to a known terrorist organisation, Al Qaida, which presents a serious threat to the US and its allies, which includes Australia. It is alleged that Mr Hicks has undertaken training with Al Qaida.

Mr Hicks and other non-US detainees at the Guantanamo Bay military facility are being detained under President Bush's Military Order dealing with the Detention, Treatment and Trial of Non-US Citizens in the War Against Terrorism. Persons subject to the Order will be treated humanely and afforded adequate food, water, shelter, clothing and medical treatment. In addition, there is a representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross at the base, who has access to the facility to independently assess the condition of the detainees, and who also has access to the detainees themselves.

Australian authorities had access to Mr Hicks in May 2002 at Guantanamo Bay. The purpose of the visit was to advance the Australian law enforcement and intelligence investigation into the activities of Mr Hicks.
The Government is confident Mr Hicks is being held in humane conditions and is in good health.

(2) The Government has an ongoing dialogue with the US on this issue, and is cooperating with the US on a range of levels, including on the issue of law enforcement. The recent visit to Guantanamo Bay is a direct result of that dialogue and our representations to the US on this matter.
During my visit to Washington in May, I raised the issue of Mr Hicks' detention with US officials.

As previously stated, Australian authorities have been given access to Mr Hicks, have made inquiries about his welfare and treatment, and have contacted his family to advise them of his welfare. Australian authorities have reiterated to the US the request from Mr Hicks' family for family access to him and access by a legal representative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

quote.para: With reference to page 9 of the Superannuation Working Groups Issues Paper, presented on 2 October 2001, which describes problems encountered by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) with some of the smaller corporate funds, where most of its enforcement action is concentrated, and to the statement by the then Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, (Mr Hockey) in presenting the paper, It is going to be hard particularly for industry funds. It is going to mean that the representatives of some workers on those industry funds, including union officials, are going to start to be held accountable for their investment decisions.

(1) Is APRA aware of any instances where trustees of industry or corporate superannuation funds who are union officials have been responsible for inappropriate conduct of the type outlined in the working groups issues paper.
(2) Did APRA provide any advice to Mr Hockey to this effect before he made his remarks on 2October 2001.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator Coonan
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) With reference to the answer to a question taken on notice during additional estimates hearings regarding the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority's new draft reporting requirements, does the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) currently collect data, in fund annual returns or by other means, on the administration and/or investment costs of superannuation or on any fees, charges and commissions levied against members accounts; if so, why is this information not made publicly available; if not, why not.

(2) What relationship, if any, is there between the data to be collected under APRA's draft reporting requirements and the disclosure requirements under the Corporations Act 2001 following the passage of the Financial Services Reform Act 2001.
(3) Has APRA held any discussions with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission about how the draft reporting standard might complement these disclosure provisions.
(4) When does APRA expect the draft reporting requirements will be implemented and the data collected first published.

(5) At what level of detail does APRA propose to publish the data collected under the draft reporting requirements. (a) Will the draft reporting standard collect data on fees and expenses only on a whole of fund basis; if so why; and (b) does this have the potential to misrepresent expenses for funds offering multiple products with different fees.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator Coonan
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Currently, APRA collects information on administration and investment fees and expenses from APRA annual and quarterly returns. This information is aggregated and published every quarter as `Operating Expenses' in the APRA Quarterly Superannuation Trends.

(2) APRA collects data for the purpose of prudential supervision - that is, for assessing the financial soundness and prudent management of superannuation funds and to ensure that member interests are protected. The disclosure requirements under the Corporations Act 2001 are for consumer protection purposes - that is, to provide consumers and investors with sufficient information to make informed decisions with respect to a financial product or service.
(3) APRA has held discussions with ASIC with regard to information sharing under the new Australian Financial Services Licensing regime.

(4) The new superannuation returns are currently in draft format and are undergoing review within APRA. It is expected that the reporting requirements will be implemented in 2003-04 after industry consultation. APRA proposes to collect data both quarterly and annually, with the information aggregated and published once it has been received and processed.

(5) APRA proposes to publish the data collected at the level it is collected, if this is considered valuable to stakeholders and provided it doesn't identify any individual entity. (a) The format for collecting fees and expenses information under proposed new reporting requirements for superannuation entities is still being considered and a final decision has yet to be made with respect to this matter. Under the draft reporting standard it is proposed fee and expense information be collected on a whole of fund basis. However, APRA is yet to determine whether to collect data on a product basis because of the practical difficulties involved. (b) If APRA were to publish data collected on a whole of fund basis, it would be necessary to clearly explain that this data is not suitable for analysis of fees and expenses at the product level.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Representing the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) (a) How many injuries were there in each of the services in the past 3 years; (b) for each year since 1998, how many individuals in the Navy, Army and Air Force were injured (separately for each service, and for permanent personnel and reserves); and (c) can these figures be broken down into the types of injury (for example, muscular strain, fractured bone, ligament damage, tropical diseases contracted).

(2) For each of the injury types identified in (1): (a) what is the average length of rehabilitation (using approximate figures based upon standard medical advice for treating the type of injury, if there are no statistics on actual rehabilitation periods experienced by Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel); and (b) for how many days on average is a servicemen or woman with that type of injury unable to engage in military training, and/or perform their regular job.
(3) How many personnel in each year since 1998 separated from the ADF indicating injury as the sole or main reason for separation (please list separately voluntary and involuntary separations).

(4) What is the system within Defence for recording injuries in the ADF (for instance, who is responsible for reporting injuries to an individual in a unit to what level in the chain of command, is there an administrative area responsible for collecting health and injury records of personnel, etc).
(5) For each year from 1998, how many injuries immediately or ultimately led to members being classed as Totally and Permanently Incapacitated.

(6) Has there been analysis done of the costs to Defence of injuries, both in terms of actual medical costs and costs involved in a member being unable to perform their regular duties for a period of time.

(7) (a) How often is such an analysis conducted; (b) when was it last done; and (c) can a copy of the most recent analysis be provided; if there is no such document, can a 2-3 page summary of ADF performance in this area over the past few years be provided, including trends and issues of concern.

(8) With reference to page 327 of the Defence Annual Report 2000-01 which states that a report was commissioned to look into the management reporting requirements needed by senior executives, commanders and managers from the Defcare system: (a) what changes were recommended in the report; and (b) what are the outcomes.

(9) With reference to page 329 of the Defence Annual Report 2000-01 which notes that certain organisational changes left personnel uncertain as to who should report and when: (a) were these changes within Defence or Comcare; and (b) what was the nature of these changes.

(10) For each year from 1998 onwards can the following information be provided: (a) the workers' compensation premiums paid to cover the costs of injuries sustained in the ADF; (b) how much was spent in the ADF on occupational health and safety training and education and other injury prevention initiatives; (c) how many personnel were receiving ongoing compensation payments as a result of an injury sustained in the ADF (indicating the total amount paid to these people); and (d) how much in total was paid by Defence to people in the form of compensation for injuries sustained in the ADF.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) Injuries recorded in each of the Services in the past three years are as follows:
* “Unknown” is where an employee's service has not been recorded.

(b) In compiling data on the number of individuals injured, an injured individual is recorded once per service per employment type (permanent or Reserve) for the calendar year in question, that is, if an employee is injured more than once in the year in question, but is in the same service for all injuries and also falls into the same employment type for all injuries, then that employee is counted only once. However, if an employee, for example, is injured twice in the year and is in the Navy for the first injury and then transfers to the Army and is injured the second time, then that employee will be counted twice - once under Navy and once under Army.

Consequently, totals cannot be automatically summed across the services or employment types to give an ADF total, as the total may not equal the sum of the areas due to individuals being represented in more than one area during the time periods given.
* “Unknown” is where an employee's service has not been recorded.
(c) A breakdown of the injuries figures provided at (1)(a) by injury nature is provided below.

entry.para: Contusion with intact skin surface and crushing injury excluding those with fracture
Diseases of the musculoskeletal system and connective tissue
