talk.start.para: asked the Minister of Defence, upon notice, on 23 May 2002:

question.para: With reference to the response to question No.13 asked in the February 2002 estimates hearing of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee, which provided the daily full cost at sea for HMAS Manoora, Kanimbla and Tobruk:
(1) Can the same daily full cost at sea be provided for: (a) the Anzac and FFG frigates; (b) the Success and Westralia; (c) the Fremantle class patrol boats.
(2) Can the equivalent average full cost for operating F/A-18s, B707s and P-3Cs. That is, the average daily full cost of these aircraft when deployed on an operation.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Past practice in answering questions of this nature has been for Defence to provide the daily, or hourly, full-cost recovery rate for ADF assets.

The full-cost recovery rate methodology is used to calculate the recovery or waiver costs of using a particular asset, usually when Defence is asked to perform a non-Defence activity. A comprehensive set of cost factors, including management overheads, capital costs and depreciation, salaries and accrued superannuation, is used to calculate the recovery rate. In other words, the rate includes all the embedded costs that Defence would be paying whether or not the assets had been deployed on operations.
The underlying assumption in recent questions and debate, that the full cost recovery rate can be extrapolated to estimate the costs of operations is, quite simply, misleading.

The true cost to the taxpayer of undertaking additional operations is the net additional cost. The net additional cost of a particular asset in an operation, in terms of extra fuel, rations and allowances, would depend on the particular operation. It also would take account of the offsets within its overall budget Defence would make in absorbing some of that cost; for example, cancelling or postponing exercises or seeking additional efficiencies to help offset the additional costs.

The net additional cost approach outlined above is consistent with the approach taken by successive Governments in providing supplementation to the Defence budget for operations - for example, the Gulf War and peacekeeping operations in Somalia and Rwanda. It is the method that this Government intends to continue to use for its own costings and to employ when answering questions about the costs of operations for purposes of more accurate debate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 May 2002:

question.para: (1) Have any Hawk lead-in fighters commenced training operations at RAAF Williamtown or the Salt Ash Weapons Range (SAWR) yet; if so: (a) in which of these two locations have the Hawks been used; (b) when did they first arrive; and (c) how many are there.
(2) (a) On how many days in each financial year since 1995-96 has the SAWR been used; and (b) how many days has the SAWR been used during the 2001-2002 financial year to date.
(3) Does the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) have any policy on what is the maximum noise acceptable for aircraft; if so, can a copy of any policy document be provided.

(4) (a) What method of noise testing is most often used for RAAF aircraft; (b) what method was used to test the Hawks; (c) if the methods are different in any respect, why was the different aspect and/or different method chosen to test the Hawks.

(5) If the policy identified in (3) specifies different acceptable noise levels for different zoning used, what are these differences, for example, what are the RAAF guidelines on the maximum and desirable decibel levels for high-density, medium-density and low-density residential areas, etc.

(6) Was any consideration given to the noisiness of the Hawk lead-in fighter when the proposal was made by the RAAF to purchase them as replacements for the Macchi; if so, at what stage of the process was their noise considered (for example, in the first 2 months after the proposal was formulated, 2 weeks before it was put to the Minister, etc.).

(7) What is the noise range of Macchi aircraft used at Williamtown and SAWR; please provide both the minimum and maximum decibels recorded at any time during the Macchi's use in both of these locations.

(8) (a) What is the possible noise range of Hawk lead-in fighters (in other words the minimum and maximum decibels at which they are capable of operating); and (b) what were the recorded noise levels of the Hawks at Williamtown and SAWR over the duration of their activities in either of these places (please provide the maximum, minimum and average noise recorded and specify the period over which the average is calculated).
(9) How often, and from which point or points in Williamtown and SAWR, have Hawk noised levels been recorded (please provide the dates and time of day and night the noise was gauged).

(10) On any of the occasions set out in the answer to (9) was there more than one RAAF aircraft operating in the area and was the noise of the aircraft also recorded; if so: (a) what type of aircraft was operated simultaneously or overlapping with a Hawk; (b) what are the maximum and average decibel levels of such aircraft; and (c) can a copy of the noise records of such aircraft over the relevant period be provided.

(11) Were any of the noise tests conducted on the Hawk for the purpose of data-collection for the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) prepared for introduction into service of the Hawk at Williamtown and SAWR conducted at less than full throttle.

(12) Was a toxicologist asked to assess the physiological effects on humans resulting from exposure to loud noise as part of the preparation of the draft EIS or, alternatively, if anyone was requested to assess this effect, and the person was not a toxicologist, what formal qualification did this person have.

(13) (a) How many flights in total have all the Hawk aircraft taken in the Williamtown and SAWR area since their arrival; (b) from what starting date is this figure calculated; and (c) how is the Williamtown/SAWR area defined.

(14) Can the figure in (13) be broken down into: (a) the total number of flights made by each of the Hawks since their commencement at RAAF Williamtown; and (b) the number made by each for each month since their commencement.

(15) Using the definition of the Williamtown/SAWR area adopted in (13), is more than one of the Hawks ever used in the area at the same time; if so, approximately how often, in percentage terms (for example, 75 per cent of the time).
(16) Is the Hawk lead-in fighter 10 decibels noisier than the Macchi.
(17) When was the decision made to prepare an EIS.
(18) Was the EIS prepared in response to community concerns rather than as a legal requirement.
(19) How many days did the draft EIS take to prepare (including as a separate figure what dates the data relied upon in the EIS was collected).

(20) Was any monitoring conducted of fuel contamination levels in rainwater tanks in the Williamtown/SAWR are for the purpose of preparing the EIS; if so, can a copy of the study be provided; if not, why not.
(21) Does the RAAF have water delivered to the SAWR, whereas in the past it has used water tanks on or near the SAWR for drinking water; if so, when did the water tanks ceased to be used.
(22) (a) When was the last time atmospheric tests were conducted in the Williamtown/SAWR area; and (b) what did the results show.
(23) What is the lowest level that Macchi have flown at in the Williamtown/SAWR area (please give the answer in feet or metres and give an approximate answer if there is no completely accurate data).

(24) What is the lowest level that Hawks have flown, and are intended to fly, during future training exercises at Williamtown and SAWR (please give the answer in feet or metres and give an approximate answer if there is no completely accurate data).

(25) (a) What types of training operation are conducted by the RAAF in the SAWR (for example, live-firing, bombing, fuel-dumping etc.) and (b) what percentage of all RAAF activities in the SAWR does each of the activities in (a) represent (approximately if no precise figures are available).
(26) How many square kilometres does the RAAF need to conduct all of the operations described in the answer to (19).
(27) Has the RAAF ever conducted any of the activities intended to be conducted within the SAWR outside the gazetted area; if so, when and why.
(28) On average, how many litres of fuel do the Hawks burn per hour and how many litres of fuel do the Macchis burn per hour.
(29) Can the Minister confirm that there are no limitations on RAAF bombing activity at SAWR during high-danger fire periods.
(30) Have there been any back-burning or firewall-creation activities on the RAAF base at Williamtown or the SAWR.
(31) (a) Do Hawks eject the cases for 30 millimetre cannon shells; and (b) how many shells is a Hawk designed to carry on a practice operation.
(32) Have any phone calls made by members of the local RAAF Consultative Committee to the RAAF Williamtown base since June 2001 been electronically recorded (by audiotape or otherwise).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(a) Hawk training has commenced at Williamtown and SAWR.
(b) The Hawk lead-in fighters first arrived at Williamtown in March 2000. The first deliveries to the RAAF occurred in October 2000.
(c) There are currently 19 Hawk lead-in fighters based at RAAF Williamtown.
(2) (a) The following calendar year SAWR usage data is as follows (Note: data held is by calendar year):
(b) For financial year 2001-02, until March 2002 the Hawk lead-in fighters have used the SAWR for 39 days in total.
(3) No. The RAAF complies with the Occupational Health & Safety Act requirements for personnel employed in high noise areas.

(4) (a) The method used by the Defence acoustic consultants is measurement of individual aircraft movements for subsequent analysis and calculations. This may be measured in dB(A) for the Sound Exposure Level and the Maximum Sound Level, or in dB for the Effective Perceived Noise Level.
(b) Same method as described in 4 (a).
(c) No difference.
(5) Defence plans its buildings in accordance with Australian Standard 2021. The standard specifies what types of buildings can be constructed in the various Australian Noise Exposure Forecast zones.

(6) The noise level requirement for the Hawk lead-in fighter was considered during the development of the specification for the Request for Tender in 1995. The noise level requirement in the June 1997 contract specification for the Hawk 127 is:

“The Aircraft shall meet the requirements of International Civil Aviation Organisation Standard, International Standards and Recommended Practices, Environmental Protection, Annex 16, Volume 1, Chapter 2 noise requirements.”
The Commonwealth has verified through the aircraft acceptance process that the aircraft meets the contract specification.
(7) As the Macchi is not in Defence service it is not possible to measure the aircraft noise emissions.

(8) (a) Assuming the point of interest is directly below the aircraft overflying at 1000 feet altitude with 100% thrust and at a speed of 263 knots, the L(A)max is 97.1 dB(A). For the same altitude, with 80% and at a speed of 163 knots, the L(A)max is 70.2 dB(A).

(b) While the Hawk lead-in fighters were conducting training at SAWR, measurements were taken at four locations. The aircraft noise was measured at Medowie with minimum less than 45.0 dB(A), maximum less than 65 dB(A) and the mathematical average 56 dB(A), at Salt Ash Public School with minimum less than 45 dB(A), maximum 76.9 dB(A) and the mathematical average 72.4 dB(A), at Salt Ash Township - Tonia Avenue with minimum 66 dB(A), maximum 91.9 dB(A) and the mathematical average 80 dB(A), and at Moffats Road with minimum 62 dB(A), maximum 83.4 dB(A) and the mathematical average 73.4 dB(A). The average noise was not measured on this occasion.
(9) Noise level measurements included in the EIS were taken simultaneously on Monday 4 March 2002 between 1500 and 1545 hours at the following locations:
Tonia Avenue, Salt Ash;
Salt Ash Public School, Nelson Bay Road, Salt Ash;
Koala Close, Medowie; and
Moffat's Oyster Barn, Moffats Road, Swan Bay.
(10) Yes. Other aircraft overflying.
(b) For F/A-18, the maximum decibel levels are approximately 106.5 dB(A) on take-off with afterburner.
(c) Yes. A copy of this has been forwarded separately to your office.
(11) Yes. RAAF aircraft were operated throughout the throttle range required to achieve the flight profiles requested by URS Australia Pty Ltd consultants commissioned by Defence to prepare the EIS.
(12) No. A Human Health Risk Assessment is included at Appendix G of the EIS.
(13) (a) Approximately 5000.
(b) March 2000.
(c) Any flights originating from or recovering to RAAF Williamtown.
(14) Not at this time. Significant effort and dedicated resources would be required to provide a full breakdown of Hawk usage data.
(15) In general, Hawk lead-in fighters will operate in pairs from RAAF Williamtown. From SAWR primarily in a four ship formation and at times in pairs but rarely alone.
(16) As the Macchi is not in Defence service any more, the data can not be confirmed. However, it is acknowledged that Hawk lead-in fighters are noisier than the Macchi aircraft it replaced.
(18) The EIS was prepared in response to both community concerns and as a legal requirement.
(19) Preparation of the draft EIS commenced in October 2001 and was completed in April 2002. The EIS documents when all the data was collected.
(20) No. Testing of rainwater tanks was conducted from 4 June to 6 June 2002 and the results will be included in the supplementary report.
(21) Yes. Treated water is now provided to Defence members. Originally, the only water available to SAWR staff was tank water. RAAF Williamtown is investigating when tank water ceased to be used.
(22) Air quality was a topic covered in the Hawk EIS.

(a) There has been no specific ambient air quality monitoring performed at RAAF Williamtown or SAWR. The closest ambient air quality monitors are at Newcastle monitored by NSW Environment Protection Agency and Mayfield monitored by BHP and Newcastle Council. RAAF Williamtown have previously estimated emissions from RAAF Williamtown and aircraft using SAWR by using recognised published emissions estimation techniques. This was done as part of the development of an Environmental Management Plan for RAAF Williamtown and SAWR.
(b) The results from these previous estimations will be used as a guide to decide whether actual measuring of ambient air quality is required.
(23) The Macchi has flown at 50 feet during weapons passes over the SAWR and 150 feet in promulgated low flying areas.
(24) The Hawk lead-in fighters have flown at 250 feet at SAWR and in promulgated low flying areas.
(25) (a) RAAF practices bombing and gunnery training operations at SAWR.
(b) 80 per cent bombing and 20 per cent gunnery.
(26) The SAWR provides the minimum area of 2800 hectares required to meet operational requirements.
(27) Yes. Initial operational checks on the Hawk lead-in fighter gun were conducted out to sea in the Williamtown flying area.
(28) Fuel consumption for the Hawk lead-in fighter is 1250 litres per hour and the Macchi is 1019 litres per hour.
(29) No. The following limitations relate to RAAF bombing activity at SAWR during high danger fire periods:
- Flying activity must be authorised by Commander Air Combat Group.
- Open fire target illumination is not allowed.

(30) Yes. RAAF Williamtown staff conducted a hazard reduction burn in the SAWR target area in January 2002 to improve visibility of practice bombs dropped in the target area. This activity was conducted in consultation with the Rural Fire Service and is a rare event. There have been no other recorded burning activities at RAAF Williamtown or SAWR since 1998. RAAF Williamtown conducts slashing activities and maintains firetrails on Defence land in consultation with the Hunter Water Board.
(31) (a) Yes. However the shell links are retained and a case retention modification is in development.
(b) The Hawk lead-in fighter carries 60 shells on practice operations.

(32) Telephone calls to RAAF Williamtown central switch are only recorded at the beginning of a call until they are transferred to a specific extension number on base. This is documented for management and statistical purposes only. These tapes are held for a number of months. RAAF Williamtown has not directed central switch to conduct any electronic recording activity of calls initiated by the RAAF Consultative Committee.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 4 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Why are the counselling and psychotherapy professions not exempt from the goods and services tax (GST) while other mental health professions are exempt.

(2) Is it the case that there is a national regulatory body that maintains a register of counselling and psychotherapy practitioners who are required to meet clear training and industry standard requirements.
(3) Is there any evidence of the impact this lack of an exemption from the GST has had on the counselling and psychotherapy professions: if so, what are these impacts.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Counselling and psychotherapy services are GST-free when provided by registered psychologists, psychiatrists, or social workers.

The issue of the scope of health services to be GST-free was considered by the Tax Consultative Committee (Vos committee) in 1998. The Committee recommended that a range of additional services including social work services should be added to the list of GST-free health services. They also recommended that the practitioner must be a member of a relevant professional body, subject to State Government professional registration or uniform national professional self-regulation. The Government accepted the recommendations of the Committee.

The decision not to grant a wider exemption in the area of counselling services was taken in consideration of both the need to provide confidence to Australians in relation to the quality of health services provided particularly with regard to the long-standing self-regulation of the professions involved and the need to keep the GST as broad-based as possible in order to deliver the benefits of the New Tax System to all Australians.

(2) I am aware of the establishment in 1998 of the Psychotherapy and Counselling Federation of Australia Inc. as an umbrella organisation for professional associations representing disciplines of counselling and psychotherapy within Australia. Membership is voluntary and comprises affiliated professional associations that represent various modalities within the disciplines of psychotherapy and counselling.

Since its establishment the Federation has taken a number of steps towards self-regulatory practices for the psychotherapy and counselling professions, including the adoption of minimum training standards and ethical codes. The Federation is still moving towards finalising the development and implementation of these.
(3) The Department is unaware of any evidence of an impact of the lack of exemption from the GST on the counselling and psychotherapy professions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Did any investigation result from a Qantas flight that departed Launceston on 23 October 2001; if so: (a) when did the investigation commence; (b) who undertook the investigation; (c) when was the investigation completed; and (d) what was the result of the investigation.

(2) Were the findings of that investigation referred to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority General Counsel; if so: (a) why was the matter referred to the General Counsel; and (b) what was the result of the General Counsel's consideration of the matter.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised that it did conduct an investigation into a Qantas flight that departed Launceston on 23 October 2001.
(a) The matter was referred for formal investigation on 27 November 2001 and the investigation was formally tasked on 14 December 2001.
(b) The investigation was undertaken by an investigator in the Enforcement and Investigations Section of the Office of Legal Counsel in CASA.
(c) The investigation was completed on 2 April 2002.

(d) The investigator concluded that there was evidence to suggest that a number of contraventions had occurred and that consideration should be given to sending a brief of evidence to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP).
(2) Yes.
(a) Such referrals are part of the normal arrangements in the Office of Legal Counsel and are consistent with the CASA Enforcement Manual.
(b) The view of General Counsel was that there was sufficient evidence to refer the matter to the DPP for possible prosecution; as a result CASA referred the matter to the DPP on 22 May 2002.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Code of Conduct
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 353)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the Civil Aviation Safety Authority have a code of conduct in place for staff.
(2) (a) Who developed the code; and (b) when was it put in place.
(3) On how many occasions has this code been amended since it was first put in place.
(4) Does the code include a process for a review or investigation of possible breaches of its provisions; if so, what is that process.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.
(1) CASA has a code of conduct in place.

(2) (a) The Code of Conduct (the Code) was developed between the then Civil Aviation Authority and the unions party to the Certified Agreement in place at the time. (b) The Code was put in place in 1993.
(3) The Code was amended in July 1999 and again in September 2000

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Code of Conduct
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 354)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Who is the officer in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) designated as the decision-maker in relation to breaches by staff of the CASA staff Code of Conduct.
(2) What is the appeal process in relation to findings of breaches of the code.
(3) Since January 2000, how many investigations have there been of alleged breaches of the code.
(4) In general terms, what was the nature of each alleged breach.

(5) In each case: (a) what was the date of the alleged breach; (b) what was the date on which the investigation was initiated; (c) who undertook the investigation; (d) what was the result of the investigation; and (e) was there any formal, or informal, appeal or request for review in response to the recommendation or finding that flowed from each investigation.

(6) In relation to all of the above investigations: (a) on how many occasions was internal legal advice sought; (b) why was that advice sought; and (c) what action followed the provision of that advice.

(7) In relation to all of the above investigations: (a) on how many occasions was external legal advice or other professional advice sought; (b) why was that advice sought; and (c) what action followed the provision of that advice.
(8) Where external legal or other professional advice was sought: (a) who provided that advice; and (b) in each case, what was the cost of providing that advice.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice:

(1) The process for review or investigation is set out in the Discipline Policy. This policy refers to Authorised Officers and managers interchangeably as the equivalent of a “designated decision-maker”.
(2) Appeal against disciplinary action may be made under Section 2 of CASA's Staff Policy Manual, Review of Decisions - Grievances.

An employee may request a review of any decision which directly effects them. This takes the form of a grievance lodged with the manager who is the immediate supervisor of the person who made the decision. The manager must attempt to satisfactorily resolve the grievance. If the employee remains dissatisfied, then the employee must advise the manager who must refer the matter to CASA's Grievance and Appeal Board.
(3) to (8) CASA does not maintain a central database of investigations or legal advisings into alleged breaches of the Code of Conduct as the process is the responsibility of individual managers.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Code of Conduct
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 355)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

quote.para: To ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services -

(1) Where there has been an investigation into a breach of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority staff Code of Conduct, since January 2000, on how many occasions have staff sought external legal advice.
(2) In each case, who met the cost of the provision of that legal advice.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.
(1) There is no requirement for staff to advise CASA when they seek legal advice in relation to an alleged breach of the Code of Conduct.
(2) There are no provisions covering payment of legal costs by CASA.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Code of Conduct
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 356)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) staff Code of Conduct address the issues of senior officers organising meetings of CASA staff at the homes of senior officers; if so, what rules are in place in relation to the holding of such meetings.
(2) Since January 2000, on how many occasions has there been an investigation or inquiry into the appropriateness of senior officers holding meetings of CASA officers at the homes of senior officers.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.
(1) and (2) CASA's Code of Conduct (the Code) does not address these issues.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Code of Conduct
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 357)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

quote.para: To ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services—

(1) Does the Civil Aviation Safety Authority staff Code of Conduct require the recognition of the chain of command in the reporting of a possible breach of the code; if so, are there any exemptions from the requirement that the chain of command be observed in reporting possible breaches of the code.

(2) If the code does not require the recognition of the chain of command in the reporting of a possible breach of the code, what rules apply in relation to the reporting of a possible breach of the code.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.

(1) Processes for dealing with an alleged failure by an employee to adhere to the requirement of the Code are contained in the Discipline Policy, Section 5 of the CASA Staff Policy Manual. This Policy is not prescriptive regarding who may report an allegation.
(2) There are no explicit rules applying to the reporting of possible breaches of the Code, although the process itself is managed by the Authorised Officer or Manager.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Reporting of Incidents
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 358)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Was the incident referred to during the estimates hearings of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on 30 May 2002 (Hansard, p.331), reported through the proper chain of command within the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA).

(2) Given that the incident under investigation occurred in the Sydney Airline Office, would the head of the compliance division of CASA have been the officer directly responsible for overseeing the investigation.
(3) If the incident was not reported through the chain of command (a) how was the incident reported; and (b) to whom was it reported.
(4) In the first instance, was the incident reported to the CASA directly or the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.
(1) to (3) See answer 357(1.). The incident was first reported to the Manager, Corporate Support in the Compliance Division.
(4) CASA is not aware of this matter being referred to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Code of Conduct
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 359)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Is there currently an investigation into an alleged breach of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority staff Code of Conduct in addition to the inquiry referred to during the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee estimates hearings of 30 May 2002 (Hansard p.331); if so, is the same process of investigation being applied in relation to this matter as has been followed in relation to the Sydney Airline Office investigation; if not: (a) how is investigation varying from the investigation into the Sydney Airline Office incident; and (b) what are the reasons for the different approach being taken.
(2) Was this second incident the subject of a meeting in the office of the Deputy Director on 4 September 2001.

(3) During that meeting were formal written complaints, or drafts of formal written complaints, relating to this matter provided to the Deputy Director or any other senior officer who attended that meeting.
(4) If these documents were provided to an officer other than the Deputy Director, who was that officer.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.

(1) to (4) There is currently no investigation into an alleged breach of CASA's Code of Conduct, in addition to the inquiry referred to during the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee estimates hearings of 30 May 2002.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Code of Conduct
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 360)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) In relation to any investigation into an alleged breach of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority staff Code of Conduct in addition to the inquiry referred to during the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee estimates hearings of 30 May 2002 (Hansard p.331), was there a meeting in the office of the Deputy Director to discuss the investigation in the office of the Executive Manager Corporate Services Division on 28 September 2001.
(2) Was the purpose of that meeting to discuss how best to deal with the investigation.

(3) At that meeting did the Executive Officer Corporate Services Division direct, or request, that draft letters of complaint in relation to the investigation that had been provided to the Deputy Director or another senior officer at a meeting to discuss this matter on 4 September 2001 be shredded; if so: (a) what was the basis for the direction, or request, to shred these documents; and (b) were the documents detailing the complaint that was the subject of this investigation actually shredded.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.
(1) to (3) See answer to 359.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Code of Conduct
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 361)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) In relation to any investigation into an alleged breach of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority staff Code of Conduct, in addition to the inquiry referred to during the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee estimates hearings of 30 May 2002 (Hansard p.331), was there a meeting in the office of the Director to discuss issues related to this investigation.

(2) Did these discussions go to the role of the Director, specifically to statements made by the Director, or allegedly made by the Director, in relation to certain matters associated with the investigation.
(3) When did that meeting take place.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.
(1) to (3) See answer to 359.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Which Australian airports are international airports.
(2) Which Australian airports receive flights directly from South Korea.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) International airports in Australia are divided into five categories:

Major International Airports are airports of entry and departure for international air traffic where all formalities incident to Customs, Immigration, Health and similar procedures are carried out. The following airports are Major International Airports:
Adelaide
Brisbane
Cairns
Darwin
Melbourne
Perth
Sydney

Restricted Use International Airports are airports of entry and departure at which formalities incident to Customs, Immigration, Health and similar procedures are made available on a restricted basis to flights with prior approval only. The following airports are Restricted Use International Airports:
Avalon
Broome
Canberra
Coffs Harbour
Coolangatta
Hobart
Learmonth
Lord Howe Island
Newcastle
Port Hedland
Townsville

External Territory International Airports are airports of entry and departure for international air traffic located on an External Territory of Australia, where all formalities incident to Immigration, Health, Territory Customs, and similar are available. The following airports are External Territory International Airports:
Christmas Island
Cocos (Keeling) Islands
Norfolk Island

International Non-Scheduled Flight Airports are airports at which approval may be granted, provided the prescribed prior notice is given, for international non-scheduled flights only. No other form of international operation is permitted. Horn Island is the only Australian airport currently designated as an International Non-Scheduled Flight Airports.

In addition, there are a number of Alternate Airports to International Airports. These airports are airports specified in the flight plan to which a flight may proceed when it becomes inadvisable to land at the airport of intended landing. The level of formalities incident to Customs, Immigration, Health and similar procedures provided may vary according to the location of the airport and the amount of notice of the intended diversion given to authorities.
Temporary designation as an international airport may also be given to other airports when required, after approval from border and other relevant agencies.
(2) Brisbane and Sydney are the only airports in Australia receiving scheduled direct flights from South Korea.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What are the current achieved x-ray scanning rates of baggage and parcels for quarantine purposes at Australian international airports.
(2) What are the current achieved rates of searching passengers and their belongings for quarantine purposes at Australian international airports.
(3) What are the current achieved x-ray scanning rates of baggage and parcels for quarantine purposes at Australian international airports, which receive flights directly from South Korea.
(4) What are the current achieved rates of searching passengers and their belongings for quarantine purposes at Australian international airports, which receive flights directly from South Korea.
(5) What are the target x-ray rates for scanning of baggage and parcels for quarantine purposes at Australian international airports, which receive flights directly from South Korea.
(6) What are the target rates for searching passengers and their belongings for quarantine purposes at Australian international airports, which receive flights directly from South Korea.

(7) By what date were each of the above targets to be achieved (and were they so achieved) for: (a) Australian international airports, which receive flights directly from South Korea; and (b) all other Australian international airports.
(8) What is the current number of Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS) staff at each Australian international airport.
(9) What is the current number of AQIS staff at each Australian international airport, which receives flights directly from South Korea.
(10) What is the projected number of AQIS staff at each Australian international airport for the period of 15 July 2002 to 31 July 2002.
(11) What number of AQIS staff would be required at each Australian international airport to achieve a rate of 100 per cent for searching passengers and their belongings for quarantine purposes.

(12) What other sections or divisions within AQIS would need to provide resources (both human and material) to Australian international airports, which receive flights directly from South Korea to achieve a rate of 100 per cent for searching of passengers and their belongings for quarantine purposes.

(13) Which Australian international airports will have the number of AQIS staff reduced during the period 15 June 2002 to 15 August 2002 to ensure that Australian international airports which receive flights directly from South Korea achieve a rate of 100 per cent for searching of passengers and their belongings for quarantine purposes.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The national intervention level for quarantine purposes at Australian international airports is approximately 86%. Intervention involves responses to passenger declarations, profiled targeting, detector dog surveillance, x-raying and physical inspection of baggage or a combination of these measures. Of the national intervention level, the elements of x-ray intervention and physical searches of baggage are estimated nationally to be 61% and 36% respectively for all arriving international passengers.
(3), (4),(5) and (6) All passengers originating from South Korea who are arriving at Australian international airports are being targeted for quarantine intervention.

(7) A national target of 81% quarantine intervention for all arriving passengers was to be achieved by 30 June 2002. It is estimated that this target was achieved during March 2002. The risk profile for flights emanating from South Korea has ensured that all passengers arriving in Australia from South Korea since the outbreak of Foot and Mouth Disease have been targeted for quarantine intervention.
(8) The current number of full-time equivalent AQIS employees located at international airports are:

(9) Flights arrive directly from South Korea at international airports located in Sydney and Brisbane. Passengers arriving from South Korea also transit to Melbourne. The full time equivalent AQIS staff at these international airports are those specified in the answer to Question 8.
(10) The estimated number of AQIS staff at international airports during this period is expected to be in accordance with the answer to Question 8.

(11) 100% quarantine intervention is being achieved at international airports except for some airports during peak periods. The intervention limitations during these peak periods are largely related to the physical capacity of the airport terminals rather than the number of AQIS staff. The number of additional AQIS staff that would therefore be required would depend on the airport infrastructure and the number of inspection benches, x-ray machines and detector dog teams that could be deployed within the available space.
(12) All passengers originating from South Korea who are arriving at Australian international airports are being targeted for quarantine intervention.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service: Meat Exports
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 364)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What has been the total value of Australian red meat exports, by year, over the past 5 financial years?

(2) When did the Australian Quarantine & Inspection Service (AQIS) first become aware of the problem of apparent organised crime involvement in the trade of contaminated meat being sold under forged Australian quarantine seals and health certificates?

(3) When did the Minister first become aware of the problem of apparent organised crime involvement in the trade of contaminated meat being sold under forged Australian quarantine seals and health certificates?

(4) What is the extent of the problem in terms of: (a) metric tonnage sold in this manner globally per annum; and (b) the damage, in Australian dollars per annum, done to the Australian meat export industry by way of lost sales?
(5) What action has been taken to date by AQIS to combat the trade of contaminated meat being sold under forged Australian quarantine seals and health certificates?
(6) What action has been taken to date by the Minister in relation to the trade of contaminated meat being sold under forged Australian quarantine seals and health certificates?
(7) Besides the AQIS Investigation Branch, what other Commonwealth agencies are involved in this investigation?
(8) What is the particular role of each Commonwealth agency in this investigation?
(9) How are the various Commonwealth agencies involved in this investigation being coordinated to ensure that the investigation is most effective?
(10) What agencies from other nations is the Commonwealth working with to combat the trade of contaminated meat being sold under forged Australian quarantine seals and health certificates?
(11) What is the quantum of funding the Government has committed to combating this illegal trade for the 2002-03 and 2003-04 financial years?
(12) How much of this funding is being allocated to agencies from other nations with which the Commonwealth is working to combat this illegal trade?
(13) What are the current penalties for persons convicted of trading in contaminated meat sold under forged Australian quarantine seals and health certificates?
(14) Have these penalties been amended since 30 June 1998; if so: (a) when: and (b) what are the nature of the changes to the penalties?

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) The following information regarding the value of red meat exports has been extracted from records held by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics:

(2) There have been a small number of detections of forged Australian health certificates being generated and presented in the international market place in the past 18 months. These forged documents have been used to represent product from unknown sources. There is no specific evidence of organised crime involvement in these matters.

(3) There is no specific evidence of organised crime involvement. An article in the Melbourne Herald Sun on 5 June 2002 claiming organised crime involvement misquoted an AQIS officer, and the Minister was briefed to that effect on that day.
(4) During the past 18 months 233 metric tonnes of meat of unknown origin were the subject of forged Australian documentation. There is not evidence of any lost sales as a result of these forgeries.

(5) AQIS investigates all matters of forged Australian export documentation that come to notice, and where evidence is available, those matters are referred to the Commonwealth DPP. Additionally, AQIS has identified vulnerabilities in health certificates and is introducing a new form of paper with enhanced security features to further minimise the risk of forgery. AQIS, in conjunction with major trading partners, is also reviewing methods to attain optimum acceptance of electronic export documentation for meat products, reducing the scope for forgery of health certificates.

(6) The Minister supports the ongoing work of AQIS investigations into these matters, and where evidence is available, encourages referral of the matter to the Commonwealth DPP. The Minister also encourages the pursuit of the development of preventative measures by AQIS to discourage fraudulent activities.

(7) The Australian Customs Service, Australian Federal Police (Interpol Office), the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Securities and Investment Commission, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Austrade and various State Police Forces.
(8) The particular role of each Commonwealth agency has been one of facilitating requests from AQIS for intelligence information sharing, investigation liaison and evidence collection.
(9) AQIS coordinates the effective use of particular agency services/facilities and leads the investigation management phase of such criminal investigations.
(10) In addition to using the overseas AFFA Agricultural/Veterinary Counsellors, the following overseas agencies have been utilised/contacted in such inquiries:
European Anti Fraud Office (OLAF)
New Zealand Customs Service
New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry
Taipei Economic and Cultural Office
Hungary Chief Veterinary Office
Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore
Australian Commerce and Industry Officer Taipei
Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine Council of Agriculture, Executive Yuan , Taiwan (BAPHIQ)
(11) The Compliance & Investigation Program received funds of $2,515,000 for 2001/2002 for work, including investigation of these matters.

(13) In the Australian jurisdiction the offence of forgery or similar acts covers a range of offences under Part 7.7 of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (`The Criminal Code'). The offence of forgery under section 144.1 of the Criminal Code carries a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment upon conviction. The Court also has the discretion (under section 4B of the Crimes Act 1904) to impose a pecuniary penalty, upon conviction, to a maximum fine of $13,200 for an individual or $66,000 for a company.

(14) Yes. The current penalties reflect the harmonising amendments to the Criminal Code as of 24 May 2001, when a range of forgery/falsity offences that were listed under various Commonwealth Acts (including the Export Control Act 1982) were repealed. The equivalent codified offences, reflecting modern concepts of criminal responsibility, were enacted on the same date.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 12 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the number of veterinarians currently practising in Australia.
(2) `How many of the total fit into the following age group cohorts: (a) 20-29 years of age; (b) 30-39 years of age; (c) 40-49 years of age; (d) 50-59 years of age; and (e) 60-69 years of age.
(3) What number in each age group cohort are women.

(4) What is the number of veterinarians currently practicing in rural and regional Australia (that is, outside the official city boundaries of Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, Darwin, Perth and Adelaide).

(5) How many of the total of veterinarians currently practicing in rural and regional Australia fit into the following age group cohorts: (a) 20-29 years of age; (b) 30-39 years of age; (c) 40-49 years of age; (d) 50-59 years of age; and (e) 60-69 years of age.
(6) What number of veterinarians currently practicing in rural and regional Australia in each age group cohort are women.

(7) Following the Government's budget announcement to provide five scholarships to veterinary students through the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, can the Minister advise: (a) what is the progress of stakeholder consultation; (b) who in terms of individuals and interest groups have been consulted; (c) who in terms of individuals and interest groups remains to be consulted; and (d) for those who remain to be consulted, what is the target date for completing this consultation process.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) According to Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) data (Veterinary Services 8564.0), in 1999-2000 there were a total of 4,778 veterinarian general practitioners and specialists.

A report to the Board of the Australian Veterinary Association (AVA) by Emeritus Professor Trevor Heath gives a total of 6,358 registered veterinarians for 2001. This figure is derived as at June 2001 from Veterinary Surgeons Boards or their equivalent. It includes veterinarians working in other fields such as government service or in laboratories and includes those in part-time and casual veterinary work, and those not engaged in veterinary activity. Veterinarians may be registered in more than one jurisdiction.

Data drawn from the National Animal Health Information System (NAHIS), managed by Animal Health Australia, provides a 2001 figure of 7,527 veterinarians. This figure encompasses veterinarians working in veterinary-related fields and includes veterinarians not registered with the Veterinary Surgeons Boards.
(2) The ABS, AVA and NAHIS data referred to in the response to question 1 is not published according to age group cohorts.

(3) The ABS, AVA and NAHIS data referred to in the response to question 1 is not published according to age group and gender. The ABS data states that of the total of 4778 veterinary practitioners, 1964 (41%) were female. The AVA data shows that of the total of 6,358 veterinarians, 2,475 (38.9%) are female. No information on gender is provided by the NAHIS data.
(4) According to the AVA data, of the total of 6,358 veterinarians, 2,476 were in rural areas (that is outside the capital cities and Newcastle, Townsville, Cairns and Alice Springs).
(5) No information is available from the ABS, AVA or NAHIS data on veterinarians in rural and regional Australia by age.

(6) No information is available from the ABS, AVA or NAHIS data on veterinarians in rural and regional Australia by age and gender. According to the AVA report, of the total of 2,476 veterinarians in rural areas, 866 (35%) were female.

(7) (a) The program for funding five scholarships per year to veterinary science graduates who are interested in working with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is currently in the early stages of development.
(b) At this stage, no formal consultations have occurred.

(c) This has not been finally determined, but consultation with external stakeholders such as university veterinary science schools, and the Australian Veterinary Association will form a key part of the development stage. This development stage includes undertaking research on the most appropriate methodologies for marketing and implementing the program, and methodologies for identifying and assessing suitable candidates.
(d) AQIS anticipates consultation with stakeholders from July 2002, with a view to commencing the program from the beginning of 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 13 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the standard length (in years) of an undergraduate course at an Australian university which can directly result in students graduating with a Bachelor of Veterinary Science degree.

(2) What is the standard length (in years) of a postgraduate course at an Australian university which can directly result in students graduating with a Master of Veterinary Science degree or higher veterinary degree.

(3) What is the current total Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) contribution over the full life of the standard duration of a Bachelor of Veterinary Science degree that the Federal Government requires to be paid by an undergraduate student pursuing a course that could directly result in that student graduating with a Bachelor of Veterinary Science degree.

(4) What is the current total HECS or other contribution over the full life of the standard duration of a Master of Veterinary Science degree that the Federal Government requires to be paid by a graduate student pursuing a course that could directly result in that student graduating with a Master of Veterinary Science degree or higher veterinary degree.

(5) For each of the past 5 financial years, what has been the total HECS contribution over the full life of the standard duration of a Bachelor of Veterinary Science degree that the Federal Government has required to be paid by an undergraduate student pursuing a course that could directly result in that student graduating with a Bachelor of Veterinary Science degree.

(6) For each of the past 5 financial years, what has been the total HECS or other contribution over the full life of the standard duration of a Master of Veterinary Science degree that the Federal Government has required to be paid by a graduate student pursuing a course that could directly result in that student graduating with a Master of Veterinary Science degree or higher veterinary degree.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Three of the four schools of veterinary science in Australia (University of Queensland, University of Sydney and Murdoch University) offer five year Bachelor of Veterinary Science courses. The fourth (University of Melbourne) offers a four year Bachelor of Veterinary Science course but requires a pre-Veterinary year in the faculty of Science.

(2) There is no standard length for post-graduate study in Veterinary Science. While several Australian Universities offer a one year full-time Master of Veterinary Science by coursework, Masters and Doctoral degrees may be undertaken by research.
(3) The annual Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) contribution rates for HECS liable places in Bachelor of Veterinary Science courses for 2002 and the previous five years were:
The annual HECS contribution rates for HECS liable places in undergraduate science course such as the pre-Veterinary year at Melbourne University were:
(4) The annual HECS contribution rates for HECS liable places in Masters of Veterinary Science by coursework for 2002 and the previous five years were:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 13 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What is the forecast by year, over the next 5 financial years, of the number of students who will graduate from Australian universities with a Bachelor of Veterinary Science degree.

(2) What is the forecast by year, over the next 5 financial years, of the number of students who will graduate from Australian universities with a Master of Veterinary Science degree or higher veterinary qualification.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The number of students who completed a Bachelor of Veterinary Science (honours and pass) degree in an Australian University in the years 1996 to 2000 was:
and the number of students enrolled in Bachelor of Veterinary Science (honours and pass) degrees in the years 1997 to 2001 was:

While it is not possible to accurately predict course completion numbers, the steady increase in Bachelor of Veterinary Science enrolments and completions over recent years would indicate that graduation numbers will continue to steadily increase.

(2) The number of students who completed a higher degree in Veterinary Science (Masters by coursework, Masters by research, Doctorate by research or Higher Doctorate) in an Australian University in the years 1996 to 2000 was:
and the number of students enrolled in a Veterinary Science higher degrees in the years 1997 to 2001 was:

While it is not possible to accurately predict higher degree completions, the slight downward trend in Veterinary Science higher degree participation and completions over the last few years is expected to be reversed by an increase in uptake of coursework Masters courses as the result of the Government's introduction of the Postgraduate Education Loans Scheme in 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 13 June 2002:

question.para: (1) What medical research has been funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council into the causes of lower back pain.
(2) Can a copy of the reports of such research be provided.
(3) If no research has been conducted, can the Minister indicate what priority this cause of debility has in public policy.
(4) What measures has the Government adopted to prevent the causes of lower back pain.
(5) Does the Government have an estimate of the cost to the health system, including the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, of lower back pain.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In the period 2000-2002, the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) has provided $785,523 to six different projects investigating the causes of, and treatments for, lower back pain. See Attachment A for details of this funding.
(2) Copies of the final reports of these projects are not yet available.
(3) As indicated above, research has been conducted into the causes of lower back pain.
(4) No direct budget measures have been adopted to prevent the causes of lower back pain.

(5) The Department does not collect cost information on a generic health condition like `back pain' either within particular programs like the Pharmaceutical Benefits Schedule, Medical Benefits Schedule or Private Health Insurance Rebate or across the system as a whole.

In specific relationship to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme there are a number of pain relieving analgesics listed. However, none are specifically restricted to the treatment of lower back pain. Consequently, the Department is unable to identify the cost of use for this particular indication.
Attachment A

entry.para: Exercise or advice for sub-acute low back pain
Mechanisms of Disc Degeneration in the Lumbar Spine
Concentric tears of the annulus fibrosus of the intervertebral disc
Physiology and pathophysiology of truck control mechanisms
Inter-rated reliability and predictive validity of a new functional capacity evaluation for chronic back pain
Investigations on the regulation of intervertebral disc cell matrix metalloproteinases

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 13 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of the critique prepared by Animals Australia of the environment assessment report by Environment Australia (December 2001) on the Rabbit Calicivirus Suspension (Bait Delivery) Application by the Commonwealth Scientific Research Organisation to the National Registration Authority.
(2) What is being done to address the concerns raised in the critique in relation to cross infectivity.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) I have not seen this document. My Department advises me that they are aware of the critique.

(2) My Department undertook the environmental risk assessment under contract to the National Registration Authority. The overwhelming evidence from the scientific literature cited in the report concludes that that Rabbit Calicivirus does not infect and is not pathogenic to any species other than the European rabbit. This view was accepted by the National Registration Authority, the responsible decision making agency.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 13 June 2002:

quote.para: When is the National Registration Authority expected to make a decision on the proposed development of the Rabbit Calicivirus Suspension (Bait Delivery) Application by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation?

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The confidentiality provisions of the legislation constrain the National Registration Authority for Agriculture and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA) from providing specific details about an application. I am therefore, unable to provide any details regarding this application.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 13 June 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no.168 (Senate Hansard, 15 May 2002, p.1567):

(1) Did the Tasmanian experiments in question involve the introduction or attempted introduction of different generations of the E. nitens and E. globulus species; if so, (a) for what purpose; and (b) with what result.
(2) Who conducted the experiments.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Information about the experiments in question was provided under the former (voluntary) system that was overseen by the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC). Information provided under the GMAC system was supplied on a confidential basis. Information gathered under the new regulatory arrangements, which took effect from 21 June 2001, is more widely available. However, as at 21 June 2001 no work was being undertaken on the experiments in question and no applications to continue this work have been received. Therefore, no information on these experiments has been provided under the new regulatory arrangements.
(2) The experiments were conducted under the auspices of the University of Tasmania.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 14 June 2002:

question.para: With reference to correspondence from the Minister received by Senator Ridgeway on 19 February 2002 regarding overseas film and documentary makers entering Australia for work purposes:

(1) (a) How many (i) 420 Entertainment visas; and (ii) 423 Media and Film Staff Visas, have been issued by the department over the past 5 years; and (b) from which countries of origin are the recipients of the visas.
(2) How many of the applications for 420 Entertainment Visas over the past 5 years have been referred to the Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance for their input.

(3) What are the criteria that applicants are required to meet in order to qualify for a 423 Media and Film Staff Visa, in particular, is it a condition of eligibility that the material filmed in Australia will not be screened in Australia.

(4) (a) What actions have Commonwealth staff employed in national parks in the Northern Territory been directed to undertake to enforce visa requirements in those areas; (b) what form have these directions taken; (c) how many breaches of visa requirements have Commonwealth staff in these national parks reported to the department over the past 5 years; and (d) how many breaches are related to either 420 or 423 visas.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (b) The table below sets out the country of citizenship of recipients.

entry.para: 420 (Entertainment) Visa Grants (Persons) by Country of Citizenship
423 (Media and Film Staff) Visa Grants (Persons) by Country of Citizenship

answer.para: (2) Sponsors under the Entertainment Visa are required to consult with the relevant Australian union in relation to the employment or engagement of the applicant prior to lodging applications. Statistics are not held on the number of referrals by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) to the Media Entertainment and Arts Alliance (MEAA) but referrals concerning subclass 420 visas are rare. This would only occur where the decision-maker has doubts as to whether the sponsor has undertaken the consultation required under Migration Regulation 420.223 or if there is a matter arising from the sponsor's consultation with the MEAA that requires clarification or further input.
(3) Visa criteria are set out in the Migration Regulations. Migration Regulation 423 sets out the following criteria for the Film and Media Staff visa:
If the applicant seeks to represent an overseas news organisation as a journalist, correspondent or reporter:
If the organisation is not represented in Australia:
· representation of the organisation in Australia would not be contrary to the interests of Australia; and

· the organisation would support the applicant financially in Australia and arrange for the applicant's departure from Australia on or before the day of expiry of the visa; If the organisation is represented in Australia:
· there is no suitable person in Australia who is capable and available to do the proposed work; and
· the work would not be contrary to the interests of Australia; and

In both cases, if the intended period of stay in Australia is more than 3 months, sponsorship by an Australian citizen, an Australian permanent resident, an eligible New Zealand citizen, or an organisation operating in Australia is also required.
If the applicant seeks to make a documentary program or a commercial that is exclusively for overseas use:
In all cases:
· there is no suitable person in Australia who is capable and available to do the proposed work; and
· the work would not be contrary to the interests of Australia; and
· if the intended period of stay in Australia is more than 3 months, sponsorship by an Australian citizen, an Australian permanent resident or an organisation operating in Australia.
If the applicant seeks to enter Australia temporarily under an agreement between Australia and another country:
In all cases:
· there is evidence that the applicant's stay in Australia under the agreement has been agreed to by the competent authorities in Australia and in that other country; and
· the application meets the requirements of the agreement.

(4) (a) DIMIA staff liaise closely with staff of Parks Australia North in both Darwin and Uluru so that checks can be made that overseas film crews hold appropriate Australian visas before they are given approval to enter and film in national parks. Environment Australia and Parks Australia North in the Northern Territory publicise visa requirements on their web-site and in the written guidelines that accompany permits to film in the parks. Park staff have been provided with details of visa requirements, training in how to check visas and asked to contact nominated DIMIA staff if they have doubts about the appropriateness of a visa.
(b) No directions have been given as all enforcement of visa requirements is undertaken by DIMIA staff.

(c) and (d) Statistical information of this type is not available although DIMIA staff in the Northern Territory report that the incidence of abuse in this area is low. There have been occasional incidents of overseas film crews entering Australia on Electronic Travel Authorities and seeking to undertake documentary film work - they have been asked to apply (and meet the requirements) for subclass 423 visas before obtaining permits to film in national parks.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 17 June 2002:

question.para: With reference to overseas documentary-makers working in Australia in co-productions with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC):

(1) What are the general terms of co-production agreements that the ABC enters into with overseas broadcasters such as the BBC, Channel 4 and WGBH Boston, which travel to Australia to film documentaries, in particular (a) what provisions are built into these agreements to directly benefit the Australian film and documentary making industries, and Australians who work in these industries; (b) how are the export earnings from these co-productions shared between the parties; and (c) what are the licensing arrangements in terms of copyright ownership of the co-produced works.

(2) In terms of the requirement in the ABC's Corporate Plan to broadcast the best of Australian and overseas programs on television, does this override the ABC's ability to give preference to Australian-made productions ahead of overseas productions.
(3) What policies or programs does the ABC implement to directly support and foster the Australian documentary production industry and those who work in this field.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The general terms of documentary co-production agreements involving the ABC are negotiated between the parties and vary widely from project to project. The key factors negotiated in any co-production include:
(9) Creative ownership of the project, such as who developed the idea and who will be creatively responsible for the production;
(10) Creative approval rights;
(11) Financial contribution of each party;
(12) Value of rights granted to each party;
(13) Equity shares;
(14) Recoupment of investment/s or equity; and
(15) Share of net profit.

Overseas broadcasters entering into a co-production agreement with the ABC will not, in the majority of cases, put together their own team of production personnel to travel to Australia. Generally, the ABC as the domestic broadcaster will supply the production team and produce the program on behalf of the co-production partners. This is the most economic and practical approach for all parties and the rationale for the parties to enter into a co-production agreement.

There are exceptional cases where the ABC does not have creative ownership of a project being filmed in Australia and is a minority financial partner. In these circumstances, the ABC will contribute some production personnel. In addition, all film and tape stock is purchased in Australia and film processing and transferring takes place locally.
In relation to part (a), as stated above, the ABC will provide the production personnel for the majority of documentary co-productions produced in Australia.

In relation to part (b), net profits (`export earnings') are generally shared between the co-production parties in proportion to their respective financial contributions to the production budget of the co-production.
In relation to part (c), copyright ownership is generally shared in the same proportion as each party's financial contribution to the production budget of the co-production.

(2) No. The ABC has a long history of providing opportunities for Australian productions. The ABC provides the most comprehensive Australian documentary output of any Australian broadcaster, commissioning approximately sixty hours of documentary programs annually, including natural history, arts and social documentaries. The ABC regularly enters into co-production agreements with Australian producers. This is part of the ABC's overall annual production output of almost 350 hours of factual programs.
(3) The ABC has a number of policies and initiatives in place to directly support and foster the Australian documentary production industry and those who work in this field. These include:

(16) An output deal with Film Australia Limited to support the production of up to ten hours of Australian-produced documentaries each year for the four year period 1999/2000, 2000/2001, 2001/2002 and 2002/2003;

(17) The ABC/Australian Film Finance Corporation (FFC) Production Accord to assist with the production of up to 14 hours of Australian “Accord” documentaries (and a number of other Australian “non-Accord” documentaries per year);
(18) The ABC also enters into agreements with State film and television development agencies and offers development funding initiatives directly to Australian producers;
(19) The ABC publishes information on how to engage in development and production with the ABC. Guidelines are available on the ABC website and in hard copy; and
The ABC commissions music and graphics from Australian composers and graphic artists.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that United States (US) military bases in South Korea are polluting the Han River with oil and toxic chemicals.

(2) What action will the Minister take through the ANZUS Treaty and other relationships with the US to urge that military bases in South Korea and other Asian and Pacific countries meet environmental operating standards at least as stringent as would apply in the US or Australia and are cleaned up when they close.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am aware that such claims have been made by Republic of Korea (ROK) authorities. It is my understanding that the United States does not dispute the existence of traces of kerosene which may have emanated from US military bases and is jointly investigating this matter with the ROK authorities. Allegations relating to toxic chemicals have yet to be clarified.
(2) These issues are being appropriately addressed in dealings between the government of the relevant host country (the ROK) and the United States Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 June 2002 :

question.para: (1) Does the Government support the current initiatives to achieve a lasting peace in Sri Lanka?
(2) What concrete initiatives has the Government taken to support the peace process?
(3) Can the Minister provide advice on Sri Lankan or other international responses to its efforts in this regard?
(4) Is the Minister aware of any approaches for Australia to contribute to peacekeeping efforts in Sri Lanka in the event of such actions being considered as part of any peace settlement?

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The Government has both publicly and privately expressed to the Sri Lankan Government our support for the peace process. Representatives of the Sri Lankan Tamil community in Australia have also been urged by Australian Government officials to use whatever influence they can to ensure that the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) desist from recruiting child soldiers, respect the political and human right of Muslims and other minorities in the areas they control and respect the rights of Sri Lankan Tamils who choose not to support the LTTE. Although the peace process is in its very early stages, the Government is already examining ways in which Australia's development assistance can be used to support the peace process.
(3) Australia and Sri Lanka have enjoyed close relations for many years. The Sri Lankan Government understands and appreciates Australia's support for the peace process.
