talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that the United Kingdom (UK) War Pensions Agency is now awarding war pensions to nuclear test veterans, including those who were at Monte Bello and Maralinga, for cancers of the pharynx, the colon and the prostate and for multiple myeloma and generalised anxiety conditions.

(2) Is the Minister aware that the New Zealand (NZ) Government has recently announced that the crewmen of HMNZS Otago and HMNZS Canterbury who were sent by the NZ Government to protest the French nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll in 1973 have been provided with full war pension access.
(3) Will the Australian Government adopt either the UK or the NZ approach to war pensions for Australian nuclear test veterans; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Veterans' Affairs has advised that claims from British ex-service personnel who took part in British atmospheric nuclear tests during the 1950s and 1960s are dealt with in accordance with the legislation which provides that a war pension may be awarded where there is reliable evidence to suggest that disablement is due to service.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs also advised that in the United Kingdom, following the findings of the independent National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB) studies on nuclear test participants, awards based on presence at UK atmospheric nuclear test detonations can be made for certain conditions only. These conditions are leukaemia (other than chronic lymphatic leukaemia) and primary polycythaemia rubra vera if their clinical onset is within 25 years of first visiting the sites.

Following the release of the initial NRPB Report in 1988, multiple myeloma was included as a condition which could be accepted as a matter of course on the basis of presence at nuclear test detonations. However a further NRPB report, released in 1993 and using an additional 7 years of data, concluded that the data did not support the risk of developing multiple myeloma. Since then, on the basis of presence at atmospheric nuclear test sites, new claims for multiple myeloma have been rejected.

The British advise that these reports did not causally link development of those conditions to ionising radiation exposure and the policy is not an acknowledgment that those present at the tests were exposed to harmful levels of ionising radiation. The accepted service link is purely presence at the test sites.

The British Secretary of State does not automatically accept that those present at UK atmospheric nuclear test detonations and clean up operations were exposed to harmful levels of ionising radiation as a result of service in these locations in the armed forces. Individual claims are decided on a case by case basis.

The Veterans' Agency, formerly known as the War Pensions Agency, advises that it is unable to provide any evidence to suggest that awards in respect of cancers of the pharynx, the colon and the prostate and for multiple myeloma and generalised anxiety conditions have been made to nuclear test veterans who were at Monte Bello and Maralinga.
(2) Yes. This announcement was made by the Hon Mark Burton MP, New Zealand Minister of Veterans' Affairs, on 11 June 2002.

(3) At present Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel involved in the British nuclear tests in Australia can make claims for compensation and treatment under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRCA) for any injury or illness that results from their service or participation in the tests.

The Government has established the Review of Veterans' Entitlements (Clarke Review) to consider perceived anomalies in the eligibility of ADF personnel to claim under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA). The Review is considering submissions from groups representing participants in the British nuclear tests for access to benefits under the VEA. The Government will await the outcome of that Review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 25 June 2002:

question.para: (1) (a) Is it a fact that, as reported previously in released documents, the 1994 report of the Australian Geological Survey Organisation's North East Study costs $1000; and (b) can a full list be provided of the companies or organisations that have purchased that report.

(2) With reference to the indefinite moratorium on petroleum exploration activities immediately adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park announced by the Government in July 1990: (a) is that moratorium still in force; if not: (i) when did it end, (ii) who ended it, and (iii) what reasons were given for its termination; (b) what areas does Geoscience Australia (GA) understand are included in the moratorium; and (c) what activities are deemed to constitute exploration for the purposes of the moratorium.
(3) Did the 1999 Franklin Cruise conduct both core sampling and seismic surveying.
(4) Was part of the Franklin's objective ensuring that the Ocean Drilling Program (leg 194) did not encounter hydrocarbons.
(5) Could any of the data derived from the Franklin Cruise be used to assist in determining petroleum prospectivity in the North East Region.
(6) When did the Australian Geological Survey Organisation (AGSO) commit to the Franklin Cruise.
(7) Does the SAR satellite data purchased by AGSO indicate areas of oil and/or hydrocarbon seepage; if so, where.
(8) For what areas has SAR data been purchased.
(9) What is the total cost of the SAR data acquired.
(10) What is the total cost of determining weather compliance for the data purchased.
(11) Has the SAR data been provided, either directly or indirectly, to any organisation or company.
(12) Is the data, or summaries of the data, for sale; if so, at what charge.

(13) Is the definition of exploration given by Dr Powell, Deputy CEO and Chief, Petroleum and Marine Division, Geoscience Australia, during an estimates hearing of the Economics Legislation Committee (Hansard, 3 June 2002, p.89) and accurate definition of `exploration' as used by GA; if not, what is the definition used by GA.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Australian Geological Survey's Record 1994/50 Structural and stratigraphic evolution of the Townsville Basin, Townsville Trough, offshore northeastern Australia was originally offered for sale for $ 950. Following the introduction of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) the price was $ 931.95 plus GST.
(b) No. The information sought will not be released for commercial confidentiality and privacy reasons.

(2) (a) Minister for Resources Alan Griffiths announced on 17 July 1990 (DPIE Press Release 90/158G) that: “there will be no exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Any exploration in close proximity to the Park is extremely unlikely and would only be allowed, if at all, under strict environmental control.” Mr Griffiths' Press Release then stated that exploration was warranted in a number of sedimentary basins outside the Park boundaries. He also stated that detailed consideration would be given to the conditions under which permits in these basins would be granted, in consultation with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Prime Minister Bob Hawke reiterated the Government's views in an address to the National Press Club on 19 July 1990. Geoscience Australia has no record of an “indefinite moratorium on petroleum exploration activities immediately adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.”
(b) Geoscience Australia understands that no petroleum exploration activities are permitted within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.
(c) The main activities constituting petroleum exploration are detailed, grided industry seismic surveys designed to locate potential drilling targets, and drilling petroleum exploration wells.

(3) Yes. The 1999 Franklin Survey obtained 1700 line-km of seismic data, and took seabed gravity cores and dredge samples as well as seabed photographs. This was published by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation in Aus.Geo News, 1999, 53: 5, 8.

(4) Yes. It is a key safety provision under Ocean Drilling Program guidelines that drilling sites must not be located on any structure with the potential to contain oil or gas reservoirs as these would be a hazard to drilling. These guidelines are contained in the JOIDES Journal Volume 18, Special Issue No. 7, October 1992 - Ocean Drilling Program Guidelines for Pollution Prevention and Safety.

(5) Yes. But in reality, the quality, spacing, and depth penetration of the seismic data obtained, whilst sufficient to site the shallow ODP wells, was not of a standard that would be of interest to petroleum explorers. The seabed cores and dredge samples obtained by the site survey would be all but useless as indicators of petroleum prospectivity.
(6) The Australian Geological Survey Organisation committed to the Franklin Survey in its 1998/99 Work Program, which was finalised in June 1998.

(7) The Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) satellite data purchased by Geoscience Australia offshore Queensland are currently being interpreted by a contractor, and no results are yet available to answer this question. SAR data purchased elsewhere do indicate areas of hydrocarbon seepage, particularly in the Timor Sea and in the Great Australian Bight, and with minor indications in a number of other areas.
(8) SAR data has been purchased for the following areas:
(a) Offshore North East Queensland —areas within17 to 25 degrees South and 149 to 154 degrees East
(b) Great Australian Bight —areas within 32 to 37 degrees South and 115 to 137 degrees East
(c) Offshore North West Western Australia — areas within 9 to 22 degrees South and 115 to 130 degrees East
(d) Lord Howe Rise — areas within 28 to 33 degrees South and 160 to 163 degrees East
(9) Geoscience Australia purchased 24 scenes of raw satellite imagery off eastern Australia from the Australian Centre for Remote Sensing (ACRES) in June 2000 for a total cost of $ 51,362.

(10) Weather screening of the SAR data cost approximately $ 200 per scene, and was provided by Nigel Press & Associates. The exact total cost could not be ascertained in the time available, but was approximately $ 4,800.

(11) The SAR data offshore Queensland have been provided by Geoscience Australia to a contractor (Resource Industry Associates) for interpretation. The data have not been provided to any other organisation or company.

(12) The SAR data or summaries of these data are not yet available, as interpretation by the contractor is yet to be completed. No decision has been taken by Geoscience Australia on whether or not to release these data. Under the Government's current pricing policy, if released these data will be available at the cost of either electronic transmission, or of provision of the data on other media. They would thus be available to any interested parties either free of charge, or at a nominal charge that has yet to be determined.

(13) Yes. Although Geoscience Australia has no formal definition of `exploration', the descriptions of what is generally meant by `petroleum exploration' given by Dr Powell during the Senate Estimates hearing on 3 June 2002 are accurate, and are consistent with worldwide petroleum exploration industry usage.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) Since January 2000, how many reports have been lodged with the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) relating to air contamination in BAe 146 aircraft operated by National Jet Systems.
(2) In each case: (a) when was the report lodged; (b) who lodged the report; and (c) what action was taken by ATSB in response to each report.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Since January 2000, sixteen (16) reports have been lodged with the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) relating to air contamination in BAe 146 aircraft operated by National Jet Systems. Three of those reports were lodged by way of the Confidential Aviation Incident Reporting System (CAIR) and referred to incidents that had already been reported in the conventional manner. Therefore, in effect, there were 13 reported incidents.

(2) Details are listed in the table below. The date of the occurrence is listed rather than the date when they were lodged. Generally, written notification would have been received at the ATSB within several days of the occurrence. The company submitted the majority of the reports by passing the pilot report to the ATSB. In two cases the pilot in command submitted a report to the ATSB before a report was received from the company. One incident, on 20 February 2000, was also reported by Air Traffic Services (ATS).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 June 2002:

quote.para: Since January 2000, has the Australian Transport Safety Bureau received any reports relating to breaches of flight and duty times by crew operating BAe 146 aircraft for regular passenger transport services; if so: (a) how many reports have been received; (b) in each case when was the report lodged; and (c) what action was taken in response to each report.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (a) Since January 2000, two reports relating to breaches of flight and duty times by crew operating BAe 146 aircraft for regular passenger transport services have been received by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB).
(b) The reports were lodged with the ATSB on 28 September 2000 and 26 April 2001.

(c) Both reports were submitted to the ATSB by way of the Confidential Aviation Incident Reporting System (CAIR) and, after de-identification, were referred to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA).

talk.start.para: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice, on 26 June 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the estimates hearing of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on 27 May 2002, and the advice given by the Secretary of the Joint House Department, Mr Bolton, concerning the child care needs survey conducted in 2002 by the department:
(1) When will the Families at Work report on the survey of child care needs for Paliament House be available.
(2) How many survey forms were returned by each of the five parliamentary departments.
(3) For each of the five parliamentary departments, what percentage of staff returned completed survey forms.
(4) What percentage of contract workers, consultants and outsourced providers working at Parliament House returned survey forms.
(5) What is the likely explanation for the overall low rate of return of the forms.
(6) Is it possible that the apparent drop in demand for child care since the 1995 survey could be explained by the low distribution rate of the survey forms.
(7) What follow-up measures on child care at Parliament House are planned now by the Joint House Department.

talk.start.para: —the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) A draft report has been provided to the Joint House Department. That report raised a number of queries relating to some of the conclusions and recommendations made. Those queries have been referred back to Families at Work and the final report is now expected by 26 July 2002.

entry.para: Department of the House of Representatives
Combined Department of Parliamentary Library and Department of Parliamentary Reporting Staff
Department of the House of Representatives

quote.para: (4) It is impossible to calculate a percentage return rate for this group of respondents because of the changing nature of the numbers involved. However, a total of 69 completed survey forms were received from the Press Gallery, contractors and licensees.

(5) Of the 970 survey forms picked up by respondents, 510 were completed and returned indicating a response rate of 52.6%. This response rate is consistent with Families at Work's average response rate of 57%.
(6) Yes.

(7) The survey has indicated that there is an interest in utilising a child care facility at or near Parliament House. The Joint House Department has contacted Ms Sara South with a view to progressing the matter. Ms South was instrumental in the development of the Abacus Child Care Centre in the Treasury building. Using the findings of the Families at Work survey, together with Ms South's local expertise, JHD will continue to examine options for the possible development of a suitable solution to the child care issue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 27 June 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the May 2002 federal budget allocation of $211.1 million over 4 years for the purposes of reducing the current disparity in wages between nurses employed in the residential aged care and acute care sectors, and given that this difference continues to increase with nurses in aged care already being paid more than 20 per cent less in some states and territories:
(1) How does the Government intend to ensure that the money allocated is used for the purpose of reducing this wage disparity.
(2) What mechanisms will the Government put in place to ensure the money is used for nursing wages to close the gap and not used for other purposes.
(3) Will aged care providers be held accountable for how this money is used.
(4) What process will be implemented before the first allocation of monies on 1 July 2002.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) to (4) The Government provides subsidies to residential aged care providers on the basis of expected outcomes and outputs.

Under the Quality of Care Principles 1997 made under subsection 96-1 (1) of the Aged Care Act 1997, approved providers of residential care must provide the care or services outlined in Schedule 1 of the Principles in a manner that conforms with the Accreditation Care Standards, set out in Schedules 2 and 3 of the Principles.

In the 2002-03 Budget, the Government allocated $211.1 million over four years to increase residential aged care subsidies, pending the outcome of a review of the pricing arrangements for residential aged care.

The Review, at a cost of $7.2 million over four years, will examine long-term financing options for the aged care sector and will take into account the improved care outcomes that are now required under accreditation and underlying cost pressures, including movements in nurses' and other wages, and increases in workers' compensation and other insurance premiums.

As the Budget measure provides $211.1 million over four years (approximately $50 million per year) to assist aged care providers with workforce issues, the greater proportion of the funding has been directed towards high care subsidies i.e. RCS categories 1-4.
The additional funding for residential aged care subsidies involves an increase in basic subsidy rates, over and above the increases that will flow on from normal indexation, as follows:
- 1.5 per cent in the basic subsidy rates for RCS categories 1-4; and,
- 0.75 per cent in the basic subsidy rates for RCS categories 5-7.
Residential aged care subsidies, incorporating the increase, will be paid for all residents from 1 July 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 27 June 2002:

quote.para: (1) How much money has been raised by the $10 `Ansett Levy' since being introduced in October/November 2001.

(2) (a) Is it a fact that the original introduction of this levy was to fund the Ansett entitlements of annual and long service leave and the government standard 8-week redundancy, yet the Government has insisted on the money given to the Administrators of Ansett (195 million) be classed as a loan and that the Government be listed as a secured creditor, to be paid back in full; and (b) where are these funds being directed.
(3) When does the Government intend to abolish this levy or tax.
(4) Is the travelling public being misled that these monies are for Ansett by calling it the Ansett levy.
(5) Why is the money being raised by this levy not being deducted from the loan to the Administrators.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) As at 30 June 2002, $98,078,153 has been received.
(2) (a) See answers to Questions (4) and (5). (b) Airlines make a monthly payment of levy receipts to the Department of Transport and Regional Services.

(3) The levy will be maintained until the Government is completely satisfied that the Commonwealth's exposure under its guarantee to ensure former Ansett group employees are paid their entitlements is fully covered.

(4) No. The terminology `Ansett levy' is a colloquial term for the air passenger ticket levy, imposed as the Air Passenger Ticket Levy (Imposition) Act 2001 and Air Passenger Ticket Levy (Collection) Act 2001. Proceeds of the levy are used to support the operation of the Special Employee Entitlements Scheme for Ansett Employees (SEESA), which funds Ansett employee entitlements. Without the Government's assistance, Ansett employees would still be waiting for payment of their entitlements.

(5) The Government has maintained consistently that payments under SEESA are made as an advance to Ansett's Administrators, to be repaid from funds arising from the sale of Ansett assets. The Government's position as a priority creditor for these funds was agreed with Ansett's Administrators and approved by the Federal Court.

subdebateinfo.title: Family and Community Services: Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 410)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services upon notice, on 1 July 2002:

question.para: With reference to the 1992 Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement between the Commonwealth and the State of Victoria in relation to service outlets, associated funding and the timetable for transfer of services, property, equity and resources in the State of Victoria, and in particular, with reference to clause 16 (1) that addresses `property and equity' and item C that lists 6 properties either being operated, or to be operated, by the Order of St John of God, Yarraview:
(1) As the Commonwealth Government is listed as having an 80 per cent equity value in these properties, how is this being maintained.
(2) If the Commonwealth's interest is maintained, how does this occur when the Commonwealth of Australia does not appear on the titles of the properties.
(3) Is the Commonwealth aware whether the Victorian Government has any interest in these properties; if so, what is it.

(4) If the Commonwealth Government has provided 80 per cent of the costs to enable accommodation of these disabled people, is the Commonwealth aware what rents are being paid by disabled people to live in houses purchased with funds provided by the Commonwealth Government.
(5) (a) How long have these rental arrangements been in place; and (b) when did the relevant department first know of them.
(6) If the Minister discovers that rents have been overcharged, will the Minister direct the Trustees of the Hospitaller Order of St John of God to make restitution to the residents.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In general, the Commonwealth has had contractual rights in relation to equity as set out in the respective funding agreements made with organisations. In the case of services transferred to the Victorian State Government these rights were also transferred in 1992 under the Commonwealth State Disability Agreement (CSDA). The Victorian State Government now holds the copies of the funding agreements.
(2) See above.

(4) The Commonwealth's funding contribution is now provided directly to the Victorian State Government Department of Human Services which is responsible for the administration of this service, including the level of government grant to be paid and any policies in relation to rents payable by consumers.
(5) (a) Not known.
(b) Not known. The relevant Department is the Victorian Department of Human Services.
(6) This is a matter for the Victorian State government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 4 July 2002:

question.para: (1) What countries are currently indebted to Australia.
(2) What are the dollar amounts of these debts per country (please include all developing countries, not just those in the Highly Indebted Poor Country scheme).

(3) What percentage and what dollar amount of the aforementioned debts, excluding the debt from the now defunct Development Import Finance Facility scheme, have been generated from Export Finance Insurance Corporation (EFIC) facilities.
(4) What is the nature of this debt, that is, EFIC loans, credit insurance or political insurance.
(5) To what specific EFIC facilities does this debt correspond.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: All amounts are in AUD.
(1) The following countries have sovereign debt with Australia:

Bangladesh, Bhutan, China, Cook Islands, Cuba, Egypt, Ethiopia, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Nepal, Nicaragua, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Russia, Solomon Islands, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tonga, United Arab Emirates, Vietnam.
(2) Dollar amounts of Australia's sovereign debt exposure per country at 30 June 2002 are as follows. Note that not all exposure is in relation to EFIC facilities:

entry.para: Papua New Guinea (Australian Office of Financial Management, Treasury)

answer.para: (3) EFIC advises that the percentage and dollar amounts of the debts (excluding the DIFF debts) as generated from EFIC facilities are as follows

(4) EFIC advises that the nature of the debt referred to in Question 3 comprises EFIC loans, Export Finance Guarantees and rescheduled debts stemming from claims in Egypt and Russia. While the Export Finance Guarantee is a contingent liability, these facilities have been included as “debt” because the beneficiary has the ability to make a call against the guarantee in the event of non-payment.
(5) EFIC's non-DIFF exposure attaches to the following facilities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 July 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the Defence Capability Plan Supplement 2002, and, in particular, the five graphs breaking down expenditure into five broad sectors (for example, aerospace):
(1) Can the projected yearly figures of expenditure be provided for each of these five sectors, in a table format.

(2) With reference to the graph showing unapproved major capital projects by industry sector, can the projected yearly figures of unapproved expenditure be provided for each of these five sectors, in a table format.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) Yes. The projected yearly expenditure figures in the Defence Capability Plan Supplement relate to unapproved major capital projects. The industry sector breakdowns are as follows:
Projected Yearly Expenditures For Unapproved Major Capital Projects By Industry Sector
($million)

subdebateinfo.title: Industry, Tourism and Resources: Wide Bay Electorate
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 437)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 10 July 2002:

question.para: (1) What programs and/or grants administered by the department provide assistance to people living in the federal electorate of Wide Bay.
(2) What was the level of funding provided through these programs and/or grants for the 1999-2000, 2000-01 and 2001-02 financial years.
(3) Where specific projects were funded: (a) what was the location of each project; (b) what was the nature of each project; and (c) what was the level of funding for each project.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) People/organisations in the federal electorate of Wide Bay are eligible to apply for assistance under all programs administered by the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources, with applications assessed on merit and/or against relevant criteria. Information on programs administered by the Department is available through the Department's website (www.industry.gov.au) and the AusIndustry website (www.ausindustry.gov.au).
During 1999-2000, 2000-01 and 2001-02 assistance was provided to the electorate of Wide Bay through the following programs.
(20) R&D Start Program
(21) COMET Program
(22) Regional Tourism Program
(23) Regional Online Tourism Program
(24) Holiday Incentive Program
(25) R&D Tax Concession
(26) Project By-Laws Scheme
(27) TCF Strategic Investment Program
(28) Business Entry Point Program
Funding was also provided in 1999-2000 (through a specific election commitment) toward the restoration of Urangan Pier in Hervey Bay.

Note: This response does not include information in relation to science and sports programs. The Administrative Arrangement Order of 26 November 2001 transferred responsibility for science to the Department of Education, Science and Training. Responsibility for sports was transferred to the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts.
(2) The aggregate level of funding/assistance provided to the electorate of Wide Bay through these programs during 1999-2000, 2000-01 and 2001-02 is outlined in the table below.

entry.para: Restoration of Urangan Pier (specific election commitment)

answer.para: (1) R&D Start Program. Agreed funding figure reflects the initial funding awarded to projects in the relevant period; this funding is typically paid out over 2-3 years. The amount is the original funding to the project only, and minor variations may have occurred in the intervening period. Payments made figures reflect the total amount paid in the relevant years regardless of when the funding was initially awarded.

(2) Holiday Incentive Program. This Program provided rebates of $150 per household for people taking domestic holidays, under specified conditions, as an incentive designed to encourage Australians to take a domestic holiday. Payments were made to travel agents for reimbursement to their clients. Commenced in November 2001 and concluded 31 January 2002.

(3) R&D Tax Concession. Note that information can not be provided on individual registrants for the R&D Tax Concession without breaching the confidentiality requirements of s47 of the IR&D Act 1986. Aggregate data is not yet available for 2001-02.
(4) Project By-Laws Program. The Customs Administration Act 1985 prohibits the disclosure of certain information relating to PBL applicants/projects.

(5) Textile Clothing and Footwear Strategic Investment Program. The information provided attracts obligations of confidence, and we are unable to disclose identities of individual firms and the benefits they receive.

(6) Business Entry Point. The BEP initiative includes a website that provides free online government services and information for Australian businesses from all three levels of government. The website is convenient for regional Australian businesses as it saves the necessity of travelling or reliance on postal services for obtaining and lodging information. This includes information on business start-up, available assistance, taxation, licensing and legislation. Other transactions such as taxation compliance and licensing applications are also accessible through the BEP website.
(3) Details in respect of specific projects funded/assisted through ITR programs in 1999-2000, 2000-01 and 2001-02 in the electorate of Wide Bay are provided below.
R&D Start Program
A competitive merit based program which supports business to undertake research and development and related activities. Assistance is provided through grants and loans.

entry.para: Novel self cleaning tanks and central filtration system for intensive high density continuous fish production facility

answer.para: Competitive, merit based grants program which provides funding to increase the commercialisation of innovative products, processes and services by providing individuals, early-stage growth firms and spin-off companies with a tailored package of support to improve their potential for successful commercialisation.
The Government provided funding in 1999-2000 (through a specific election commitment) toward the restoration of Urangan Pier in Hervey Bay.
Provides grants between $30,000 and $100,000 to help boost the capacity of businesses and organisations to deliver higher quality tourism attractions, products and services in regional Australia.

entry.para: Hervey Bay Marine Interpretive Education Centre and Aquarium

answer.para: Provides grants between $10,000 and $60,000 to develop geographically based regional tourism websites which cover a range of tourism products and services in regional areas.

entry.para: Hervey Bay Tourism and Development Bureau Ltd

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 10 July 2002:

question.para: (1) What programs and/or grants administered by the department provide assistance to people living in the federal electorate of Wide Bay.
(2) What was the level of funding provided through these programs and/or grants for the 1999-2000, 2000-01 and 2001-02 financial years.
(3) Where specific projects were funded: (a) what was the location of each project; (b) what was the nature of each project; and (c) what was the level of funding for each project.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Veterans' Affairs administers a number of programs and/or grants:

· Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program—The aim of this program is to provide support and resources to ex-service practitioners for pension and welfare work to assist veterans and widows/widowers.
· Grants-in-Aid—The aim of this program is to assist national ex-service organisations with their administration costs in recognition of the services that they provide to the ex-service community.

· Commemorations Program—The Federal Government's commemorations program provides grants up to $4,000 to assist communities around Australia to commemorate the sacrifice and service of Australian servicemen and women in wars and conflicts since Federation.

The program enables the Government to assist communities to have a war memorial that can serve as the community focus during remembrance services. Funding assistance may be provided for the preservation, restoration or upgrading of existing memorials or, where no memorial exists in the town or suburb, the construction of a new memorial. Funding may also be provided to improve the public amenity of commemorative areas, including improving public access to, and safety of, memorials and their immediate surrounds, and to restore commemorative plaques and honour boards.

The program also enables the Government to support requests from veteran and community organisations for assistance with local commemorative activities, such as public awareness activities, restoration and display of war time memorabilia and commemoration of special anniversaries and significant reunions.

· Veteran and Community Grants—These grants aim to maintain and improve the independence and quality of life of members of the veteran community. The grants provide funding for projects which promote healthier lifestyles and enhance health, support carers, reduce social isolation and assist veterans and war widow(er)s to remain in their own homes as long as possible. Projects may meet the needs of others in the community if there is sufficient capacity.
(2) The level of funding provided by each program and/or grant to the federal electorate of Wide Bay for the financial years 1999-2000, 2000-01 and 2001-02 is:

entry.para: Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST)

answer.para: The electorate of Wide Bay has not received any funding from the Grants-in-Aid program for the 1999-2000, 2000-01 and 2001-02 financial years, since there are no national ex-service organisations presently located in the electorate. It is possible that national ex-service organisations may have dispersed part of their Grant-in-Aid to sub-branches within the electorate.
(3) (a) (b) and (c) Where specific projects were funded, the location, nature and level of funding for each project has been provided in the below table:

entry.para: Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST)
To fund a pensions officer and provide computer equipment to support the Pension and Welfare Officers at the Murgon RSL Sub-Branch.
To fund a part time administrative officer to support the Pension and Welfare Officers at the Legacy Club of Maryborough.
Provide computer equipment and internet access to support the Pension and Welfare Officers at the Murgon Ex-Service Organisation (ESO) Support Centre.
To fund a part time advocate, a part time pension/welfare officer and a part time administrative officer at the Hervey Bay RSL Sub-Branch.
To fund a part time administrative officer to support the Pension and Welfare Officers at the Legacy Club of Maryborough.
To fund a part time administrative support officer as well as financial assistance to support the Pension and Welfare Officers at the Hervey Bay RSL Sub-Branch.
Provide computer equipment and internet access to support the Pension and Welfare Officers at the Murgon RSL Sub-Branch.
To restore the Granville World War I Memorial and landscape the surrounding memorial gardens.
To publish a book about Avro Lancaster G for George, which flew 90 bombing operations with 460 Squadron.
To refurbish the Mount Perry and District War Memorial.
To replace unserviceable granite plaques with brass plaques which includes raised lettering on the Gayndah War Memorial.
To publish a book titled `Coomalie Charlies Commandos', a history of 31 Squadron RAAF operations from Coomalie Northern Territory 1942-43.
Commemorative event to combine the annual steam train festival, Train Fest 2000, and the local commemoration of Remembrance Day, A Time to Remember.
To hold a dedication ceremony to honour services of `C' Company 6 RAR to the UN transitional peacekeeping contingent in East Timor, on 15 November 2000.
To restore and repaint the cenotaph and update the existing memorial to include East Timor.
To erect a memorial to 3rd Armoured Division, which had its headquarters at Murgon during WWII (1942-43) `Brisbane Line'.
To erect a plaque in Anzac Park, Maryborough dedicated to the young men from the district who underwent National Service training between 1951-1972.
To install a bench in Freedom Park, Hervey Bay, with a plaque dedicated to the veterans in the area.
To publish a book about the Australian Women's Land Army.
To publish a booklet containing a brief history of 176 servicemen whose names are to be inscribed on three monuments within the Maryborough Central State School grounds.
To install a bench in Freedom Park, Hervey Bay, with a plaque dedicated to the veterans of the area.
To replace the flagpole which is badly rusted next to the Mount Perry War Memorial.
To erect a memorial to the 47th Australian Infantry Battalion which originated in the Maryborough and Wide Bay area. Maryborough was the headquarters of the Battalion from 1860-1960.

To erect a remembrance wall within the grounds of the Bullyard State School, to honour all men and women who served in wars and conflicts in which Australia was involved. No memorial exists at Bullyard.
To install a bench in Freedom Park, Hervey Bay, with a plaque dedicated to the veterans of the area.
To create a memorial within the Maryborough Central State School grounds consisting of three freestanding monuments inscribed with 176 servicemen's names.
To upgrade the Rainbow Beach War Memorial by adding two memorial walls, lighting, 3 portable flagpoles and slabs to support donated seats.
To install a bench in Freedom Park, Hervey Bay, with a plaque dedicated to the veterans of the area.
To provide a series of three bus excursions over a twelve month period and to promote healthy lifestyle issues.
To assist with funding the activities of a drop in and resource centre.
To establish a computer support system for veterans, ex-service personnel and dependants to enable access to departmental information.
To support a twelve month gentle exercise program for day club members.
To assist with the establishment of 10 Community Aged Care Packages in the Suncoast Hinterland Region with the provision for 2 packages for the veteran community.
